151370267.review:
I was really let down by this entry in the series. It's riddled with bugs, from vehicles freaking out and stuttering all over the place, to randomly clipping through the world, or just random things not working in general. In just 2 hours of playing this game, I saw more bugs than I have in games releasing in alpha with a single developer.
Not only is the game buggy, but the AI is as dumb as a bag of rocks, and they all share a single brain cell. I don't think the AI even knows how to fly helicopters. I've seen them crash into each other, the ground, or anything and everything else around them. When driving, they will straight up drive off cliffs to their death at full speed. I had 3 or 4 in a row drive off one after the other while chasing me, and I didn't even lead them to it.

When it comes to gameplay, it just sucks. I was constantly running out of ammo, and collecting data was extremely frustrating. You can't cancel it, it resets any time you get shot or knocked off of it, and it takes a solid 10 seconds of waiting for the AI to spawn before I'd be able to finish collecting the data. They would then shoot me, causing it to reset again. Having to do that 3 or 4 times each time I had to collect data wasn't fun. The flight controls for the helicopters are horrible as well, and it's not something that you can just fix by changing your controls. It's just how the game is. Unlike most games where you'd expect using your mouse to rotate the helicopters, it doesn't, or it does but really slowly. So rotating around is slow and clunky. It's also really stupid that the AI will shoot missiles at their own helicopters if you're hanging from them. Every time I tried to hijack a helicopter, by the time I'd reach it, it would immediately be hit and take damage.

Another thing that I found frustrating is how many AI they will send after you. You can be swarmed in seconds by a couple helicopters, jets flying overhead dropping bombs, and trucks with mounted guns firing at you. You get overwhelmed so quickly, and when you're just starting out, it isn't fun.

The game also doesn't like showing or telling you what you're supposed to be doing. After completing every mission, I'd be left confused, wondering if I was actually done or not since nothing would pop up or there'd be no dialogue telling me either. If you use the new AR thing that's supposed to light up objectives, it really isn't that helpful and only does anything when the game tells you to use it.

The menus are also confusing and the controls are weird. Why can't I just press "ESC" to go back? Why does it have to be only the delete button? "1" and "2" open the loadout menu, which is another thing that just doesn't work how you'd normally expect it to. When customising loadouts, you have to press and hold enter while using A and D to switch between options. I've never seen any game do their menu like this before. Even navigating the map or the UI in general just doesn't feel right.

I normally don't care about graphics that much, but for a Just Cause game, it is kind of expected to look good. And for something that came out in only 2018, even on very high settings, it looked like Just Cause 2 on the Xbox 360. I was also sad to discover that unlike in Just Cause 3 where you can take down entire bridges, we're back to not being able to do that again, which was one of my favourite things to do. What surprised me the most was how badly the cut scenes looked, somehow they looked worst, it was like I was watching someone else playing the game but on the lowest settings it could have been set to. They should have just animated them instead of doing it all in engine, I know that would have been extra work but at least it would have looked good, unlike what's in the game now. 

For only around 2 hours of playing this game, I had to compress my list of complaints down to a few main points. Overall, I was really let down by this game. It just feels like a cheap knockoff. Even though I bought this game on sale, I'm still going to try and refund it. Even at a price tag of $5 for the base game, and a couple dlc packs, it's just not worth the time to play the game, even if this game was free I'd still avoid it.

150099498.review: I see a lot of people have complaints about this game for various reasons which I can understand. However, in my experience the current state of Just Cause 4 is almost as good as Just Cause 3. Sure a lot of features work differently and the controls are slighter more difficult to get used to than the third game but to me it didn't detract from the experience. I got all the achievements in about 50 hours of game play. I'm glad that they changed how stuff works in this game because playing a game too similar to the third one would not be as fun. My main issue I had when playing Just Cause 4 was resolution issues and minimizing the game can cause it to crash. Turned out those two issues had workarounds. First when I switched to full screen 1920 x 1080 50 hertz the graphics were perfectly fine and actually better than the third games. This however would occasionally cause the game to crash when minimized. If I needed to minimize the game for some reason switching to windowed mode would decrease the graphic quality but would let me minimize the game without crashing. Other than that I had almost no issues when playing the game which was even less buggy for me than the previous title. All around a fun game if you don't have technical issues which some people seemed to have.

149788912.review:
This game is honestly a mess and a nightmare to play.

Same missions over and over (destroy the generators, flip the switch, hack the terminal, raise the transmitter, and then the dreaded defend said transmitter). Rinse, repeat ad infinitum.

Horrible UI and controls in general.

Driving makes you go mad, and with the amount of driving in this game, good luck. The camera angle sucks, and no way to change it. While driving you will get stuck on every little piece of debris on the road and will constantly spin out of control, and crash.

Terrible missions that are borderline impossible. Defend X mission objective - good luck without some of the DLC with overpowered weapons and vehicles. Waves of enemy tanks spawning from nowhere that will blow your defense object to hell before you even know where the missile came from.

HORRID performance. The game will stutter at times, will go from 160 fps to 20, will microstutter, and some of the "fixes" are hilarious. One common fix is to unplug your ethernet cable to fix stuttering. Even blocking all online components of this game doesn't fix the stuttering / lag, but does help a tad.

The frontlines part of the game aren't bad, just badly implemented. Just Cause 2 and 3 had it down where you just blow ♥♥♥♥ up, in this one, it doesn't matter. You don't "create Chaos" like in the previous installments, instead you fly into a base, flip some breakers, kill endless waves of enemies, die from a single sniper/rocket shot from nowhere, reload the save, and try again.

I love Just Cause for it's mindless braindead fun, but this game is just braindead unfun. Play Just Cause 2 or even 3 (which has it's own issues). This game looks great, when it's running at full performance with no hiccups, which never happens.

If you want this game, buy the complete edition for like $3, and you'll get a weekend of half-fun, half insufferable pain.

149634962.review:
Very disappointing game.
I played through the entirety of JC3 with the DLC and found myself extremely satisfied with the game's polish, performance and experience.
Enter Just Cause 4
This game taught me a brutal lesson about what happens when you don't read the Steam reviews.
Performance
Anywhere that had any sort of action immediately capped the GPU usage on my 4070 despite changing all of the settings to the lowest option possible.
Left the game alone for a month and tried it again after upgrading the RAM capacity... ZERO improvement.
Experience
All of the vehicle controls (specifically the helicopters and tanks) felt like a clown show at best.
There was no reward for blowing things up and causing actual chaos
The deployable drones were useless in combat
The weapons felt half-baked... except for the weapon ability feature; that was pretty cool

What was the lesson learned?
Immediately ask for a refund the moment you detect any faults in a game

149104326.review:
I think Just Cause 4 is just fine. I played it over 50 hours, which is rare for me, and even got every achievement. As someone who loved Just Cause 3, JC4 is a good followup with some of its' own issues. It removes some things I liked about JC3, and adds other things that I think are good. Overall, I see a lot of people comparing both games, and while that's fair and JC3 is definitely better, this is still a great followup if you want to explore, make stuff explode and follow a dumb (and at times kinda funny) story.

I did prefer the progression system of the previous game; here, you expand your frontline across the island of Solis by finishing missions in specific outposts and causing destruction to recruit more squads. It feels a lot less "direct" than in JC3, which makes it less satisfying as a result - you have to navigate to a menu, then choose a region, then expand into it - but it still has the same general effect. Destructible objects respawn after leaving and coming back later, so you can destroy them over and over - good for farming, bad for the feeling of destroying the infrastructure of an island step by step. Progressing in JC4 feels a lot more floaty and disconnected as a result, but you still do the same things you always did: blow up things and be happy about it.

There's tons of weapons, locations, stunts (a few too many to be honest) and vehicles. The driving system here is massively improved and it's actually fun to drive around! Exploring the island in your wingsuit, parachute and vehicles is as fun as ever, and coloring more and more of the island in your colors still ends up being pretty satisfying overall. It's more Just Cause, just with bad weather. Speaking of: the weather does not impact that much because it is pretty rare. There are sandstorms, blizzards, rainstorms and tornadoes, but they are all confined to rather small areas and once you finish the missions associated with them, you can turn them on and off at will. They never affected too much, but they were visually impressive at least.

The storyline is forgettable, but told tongue-in-cheek, which I appreciate. Rico is Rico, there are some familiar faces and it's all around a good time. Missions could use some more variety, as you always flip breakers, blow up generators or turbines, or hack and defend consoles, but whatever. More excuses to shoot things and blow things up. Solis as an island is pretty generic; you got desert, rainforest, lowlands and snowy mountains. The game is visually impressive however, and there are some beautiful vistas.

Lastly, the DLCs are actually pretty good as well, with one exception. Danger Rising is fun and the Hoverboard is pretty cool; Dare Devils Of Destruction is awesome because the driving is very fun. Los Demonios sucks; the infestations are annoying, the flying enemies constantly pester you and destroying the specific parts in the infestations is a hassle. It seems like a DLC not made for a Just Cause game, but luckily it's short. Still worth getting though just for the complete package.

The game runs pretty good, with one exception: on my system, any weapon that creates a smoketrail or a smoke explosion caused micro stutters. Some people report explosions in general making their game lag, but that did not happen to me. It was annoying, but rare and not unplayable.

Long story short: JC4 gets a lot of flak, some deservedly, but I think it's still an all around good time. Movement is fluid and awesome, making things explode never gets old, there is a huge variety of weapons and vehicles and I appreciate the developers being willing to try out and swap around some things to see what works while sticking to the original tried-and-true formula. If you liked Just Cause 3 and want more of the gameplay, you can't really go wrong with JC4. And if you don't like some of the changes to progression, it won't take you two hours to realize that and a refund can be made. Vamanos!

149036960.review:
Duration: 32 hours
First time played

If you've played any other Just Cause games you know what to expect.  Blow up lots of stuff. The biggest let-down in Just Cause 4 for PC is the wonky controls, which were obviously made for controller.  This leads to interesting modifications buried beneath a series of sub-menus.  You can modify your grapple, first hit "1" to enter the menus. then "2" a bunch of times to get to the correct screen. Highlight the grapple, then while holding "enter" use "a/d" to change its settings. Hit "R" to modify it, then hold backspace and "d" to change the modifications.... It's so bad that I pretty much left all my grappling attachments on one setting as changing them was too hard. 

I have a keyboard, it shouldn't be that unwieldy.  The map and calling in air drops are equally annoying.  

The story was typical fare but some of the missions felt a bit repetitive. And some were damn hard. "Killing the Bug infestations" were the worst.  I died on the last bug mission probably 20+ times.   

Still, a fun game, but I doubt I'd ever play it again. 

7/10

148473573.review:
Rating: ★★★☆☆ (3/5)

Just Cause 4 is an embodiment of unbridled chaos and destruction, offering 25.7 hours of pure, unapologetic mayhem. This game is not for the faint of heart or those in search of deep storytelling; it's a carnival of explosions and stunts, wrapped in a thin veneer of plot.

The standout feature of Just Cause 4 is the unparalleled freedom it grants the player. As Rico Rodriguez, the series' iconic protagonist, you have the world as your playground. The fictional South American setting of Solís is vast, with diverse biomes that range from dense jungles to towering mountains, and it's ripe for destruction. With a wingsuit, parachute, and grappling hook at your disposal, you can traverse the landscape with ease, creating breathtaking stunts and chaos along the way.

The game's narrative is serviceable, with Rico infiltrating a rogue paramilitary organization and uncovering a plot involving a powerful weather-controlling device. However, the story takes a backseat to the player's shenanigans. The characters and dialogue are largely forgettable, and the plot is an excuse for the next explosion or stunt sequence.

Just Cause 4 continues the series' tradition of allowing players to engage in all-out destruction on a grand scale. You can tether objects together, attach boosters for propulsion, and send vehicles and structures hurtling through the air. The environmental destruction and physics engine are the game's true stars, offering an endless array of creative ways to wreak havoc.

The visuals in Just Cause 4 are a mixed bag. The world is stunning, but character models and animations can sometimes feel clunky and outdated. The game's technical performance can also be a drawback, with occasional frame rate drops and glitches, although these issues have been somewhat improved with patches.

The game's missions vary in quality, with some being exhilarating and others feeling like repetitive filler. The AI can be inconsistent, sometimes providing a genuine challenge and at other times being astonishingly oblivious.

In conclusion, Just Cause 4 is a game that delivers exactly what it promises: unadulterated chaos and destruction. With 25.7 hours of gameplay, you've likely experienced both the highs and lows of this unpredictable rollercoaster of a game. It doesn't aspire to be a narrative masterpiece, but it excels in offering a vast, open-world sandbox for players to let their imaginations run wild. If you're in the mood for a no-holds-barred, action-packed adventure, Just Cause 4 can be a thrilling, albeit occasionally rough, ride. It's a guilty pleasure for fans of over-the-top, physics-defying fun.

148238517.review:
I love Just Cause series, but I have to join the huge group of people having massive issues.

This game is a mess, showing deep issues with leadership in a studio, where apparently nobody knew how to polish the final product - I don't care if they didn't have enough time, the end result is awful and pathetic. 

Playing this few years after release, the game still crashes and nobody knows any realiable solutions, other than updating OS or fiddling in BIOS, which I am absolutely not willing to do for one insignificant game. 

I was going to complain about other things that at times make this feel like a janky indie title and not a game that was happily being sold as AAA release - like horrible UI, which seems to be mandatory for games released under Square Enix, as I suspect they just demand the developers to make horrible, nonsensical decisions, because I don't remember the UI to be this bad in JC2 and 3. It's always good time when you can't even use mouse to properly select options, as it skips every odd choice and you have to resort to keyboard.

But ranting about amateurish UI is small potatoes to the game not even properly working on high-end PC, which doesn't have problem with most games, except those that are poorly programmed. Seems like the new generations of processors are really struggling on some games that are only few years old, but this disaster had people complaining left and right when it released, so I'm glad to see the devs didn't try too hard to solve the issues. 

I've figured I can give it a try at such huge discount, and if it's terrible, then I'll just refund it, and I'm about to do exactly that.

147286523.review:
I don't know if JC4 is necessarily a bad game, but it is definitely a bad Just Cause game. As someone with over a hundred hours in each of the previous two games in the series, allow me to describe all the ways JC4 is worse than either JC3 or JC2.

-Progression is only through story missions and stunt challenges. That's right, in the game about blowing stuff up, blowing stuff up does nothing.
-There is no more liberating bases/areas, which was the core gameplay loop of the previous games
-They removed throwables/explosives. No more grenades, no more C4 (which was arguably one of the most fun tools in the previous games.
-They NERFED ALL EXPLOSIVES, HARD. Almost everything in the game takes 2-4 RPG hits to blow up.
-Heat levels are ridiculous. If you so much as bump into a car, you immediately are hammered with endless enemy spawns, airplanes, drones, helicopters, everything, and it is really hard to get away because if you have heat and you grapple into the middle of an empty desert THEY WILL SPAWN ENEMIES NEXT TO YOU IN THE MIDDLE OF THE DESERT. Makes trying to do anything in the game annoying.
-Black market equipment drops are way more tedious. You can't get more than one item in a drop, so if you want to kit out you have to request multiple drops.
-Guns hold very little ammo, so you have to swap guns constantly. It got so annoying I installed a mod to change it.

There's probably more I'm forgetting. Honestly, even if you've already played the other games in the series, you're probably better off replaying JC3 instead of picking up JC4

146754954.review:
[h1]TL;DR just buy Just Cause 3 instead.[/h1]

...But if I absolutely [b]must[/b] say something positive, the vehicles feel a lot lighter and better to control, most weapons having two types of firing is sorta fun, the supply drop system is much better, and one(1) of the weather effects looked really impressive (from afar).

Apart from these aspects this is a straight up downgrade from JC3 in nearly every aspect. Apart from being painfully repetitive, with drawn out gunfights (with [b]VERY[/b] limited ammo), it has a boring map with no life to it, no permanent base destruction, a confusing progression system (both for the pointless grapple upgrades and the missed potential of the front line system), all held together by a dreadfully boring story with none of the charm of the previous games, with some of the worst, most padded mission structure in any game I've played in years.

Without exception, [b]every single mission[/b], be it main story or front line, is extremely drawn out and padded, sprinkled with pointless dry dialogue (which delays your mission progress btw),having to repeat the same three or five or seven hundred pointless mini objectives ad nauseum, only to find out you have to do it all over [b]again[/b] and [b]again[/b] and [b]again[/b] for essentially nothing JUST as you think you're done. I stress that this is essentially every single mission.

In essence, stay away from this game, play the superior JC3 instead, and pray that a possible JC5 will be better than this mess of a game.

by this point i had played a LOT of just cause 3, lost contact with several friends and relatives, and subscribed to martincitopants to fill the void, so i was basically a god gamer.

After the wonderful experiences that Just Cause 2 & 3 (to a lesser extent) provided, Just Cause 4 has left a sour taste in my mouth. The game is designed to waste your time at every opportunity it gets, especially with all DLC missions (i.e. enemies can & will constantly stun-lock you via the ragdoll system, mission objects are scattered across a large distance & in difficult places to find). In addition, most of your weapons are pathetically weak & not fun to use; the controls get more complicated & unintuitive which cause a ton of frustration. All of these factors are combined to make such a boring & frustrating experience.
Just Cause 4 is no doubt the worst installment of the entire franchise. You would have a far better time with Just Cause 2 & 3 or even the excellent Mad Max made from the same Avalanche Studios.

Same thing, same "scripted" single way to do it, we just did it with 3 essentially identical buildings. the second mission i did was the same completely scripted shoot at the same mix of unlimited bad guys that show up every single time until you move to the next place and start the 2 minute "helicopter extraction". Except No helicopter showed up to extract anyone or anything, just cool we did it. 
So I figured I'd try the "open world" and help fight back and its useless, they're just spawning all around you without limit, I checked a tower in the distance with a sniper scope, saw clearly that it was empty and headed that direction, then BAM, 2 enemies spawn on the tower and start shooting, a minute later its the whole helicopter coming at me over and over again. Not even that hard to fight, grapple the bottom and steal it.
I might have kept going to see if the game redeems itself somewhat but the whole thing was just odd and buggy constantly, if you get a feat, you can expect the game to freeze for a few seconds which happens constantly because I kept setting new personal best grapple distances(thankfully this lessened an hour or so in, not the freezing, me earning feats constantly). I really tried to like JC4 like i did like JC2 or even JC3. But it's just a horrible buggy mess. Some of the missions are just based on pure luck. Enemys just spawn how they want and infinitely. Doesn't matter if you are in a room with only one door which you watch or if you are on a completely empty island. They spawn everywhere and right next to you. 

if you punch someone or touch their cars accidently, you are ****ed. They instantly spawn tanks and attackhelicopters. No not onIy normal enemys. Right the hard enemys instantly. Even drones and militaryjets....
I mean in the beginning it is fun. But it's just so pointless. In a mission where you have to defend a hackingdevice. You can't just kill everyone and hack it. No you have to hack it while hoping not to be hit by an enemy explosion which will interrupt you. 

If you killed all, well they spawn right next to you and interrupt you, with infinite ammo and superaim. I had a helicopter hooked on a wall. it wiggles like crazy and the weapon is not even able to target my direction. But the enemy still keeps hitting me perfectly fine.... 

In some challenges you have to get a Car on a circle on a wall of a building. it's so high, that none of your gadgets can get it SO high. You have to bug it higher and higher with the hook. But you can't target things, because the camera is fixed on some places. If you are to slow the car explodes. If you are to fast it catapults into the sky and you miss the circle or miss the chance to enter the car while it flys into the sky. So you have restart it again....i mean for what do i need to get the car up there?...Not on a top of a building...no, on a 90° ankle wall...

Same for many other things. It's funny it can make fun. Some of the quests are interesting. But in the end the cars feel horrible. They are buggy. Sometimes you just get catapulted into the sky. On a even road. There is NOTHING. But the car just flys away. ....

Some mechanics are awesome. For example, you can destroy some bridges. There are some Weathercatastrophes, but they just look fun. But don't do much. You can have a lot of fun with the hookgadgets. But it just feels like a funny ragdollsimulator. Not a GAME. 
I really tryed to like it, but i can't take this bugfest as a "full game". It's just a funny demo which needs still at least 1 year of work to get out of the prealpha it is in...
At least it never crashed on my device. But it often lost the onlineconnection and kicked me out. 

So i can't recommend this game for it normal purpose. If you want to play a fun game and go on a mayhem. Buy JC2 or even JC3. But not this one. I even prefer the DLC-heavy JC3 over this one. 
If you want to have fun with a buggy mess? Go ahead, but at least buy it on a big discount!

144034445.review:
Probably I’m writing this too late for most of you… the game has been out awhile.  I got this on Humble some time ago, and it sat there gathering dust until one day I decided to play JC3.  But I pressed the wrong install button and ended up playing JC4.  I am a JC newb.  I played JC2 once many years ago, but I won’t be comparing this game to previous entries in the series.

This game is super fun.  It’s an action movie in video game format.  The hero you play is named Rico because of course it is.  He has a perpetual 5 o’clock shadow, and confronts enemies with his signature leather jacket (sleeves rolled up… naturally...  Rico is a man who gets to work) and worn-in jeans.  He has holsters crisscrossing his torso.  He speaks in English but with a manly Spanish accent (which probably should have been Austrian in keeping with the action hero genre).   And with his wingsuit, grappling hook, and parachute, he can do all sorts of moves not permitted by physics.  He’s basically spider-man.  That’s one of his super-powers.  The other is that he is practically immune to bullets.

There’s plenty of gunplay to be had, and all that is really fun, but the game is really about movement.  Nothing beats using his grappling hook shoot him over the heads of his enemies while they voice their amazement.  It took me a little bit to get used to the movement mechanics.  Early on, the game introduces timed missions.  These were frustrating; it took me about 15 tries to complete the first one.  But once I had the hang of it, the timed missions were no big deal.  I do admit to nearly rage quitting on the second timed mission.

The game gives you about 10 mission types (+3 more with the DLC) on repeat.  There’s two variations of timed missions, defend the base, snipe the bad guys, find the right vehicle to gain entry into the stronghold, turn off the switches, destroy the McGuffin, etc..  Then there are a bunch of little missions like wingsuit through the rings within a time limit, drive really fast through a checkpoint, crash a car – those latter ones can be completely ignored without impacting the game in any meaningful way (which I did).  The DLC missions, particularly the one about the bugs, offer more challenge, but in a good way.  Once of the DLC is a racing mini-game – but I got motion sick playing it, so that was that.

I had a great time playing the action hero.  I loved Rico’s almost irritated grunts when perforated by shrapnel.  Rico and his allies have an army, but he always goes it alone, flying into heavily defended locales, murdering his enemies, and securing his objective.  Then, moving on to the next one.  Despite the repetitiveness of the missions, I never got bored.  I loved improving my skills around Rico’s movement --  I got a Serotonin jolt every time I executed a particularly slick move.

Highly recommend this for people who like the 3rd-person action genre, particularly if you prefer games that prioritize senseless violence over story.

142984661.review:
Graphics:
Visually, this offers breathtaking landscapes and impressive environmental details. The diverse biomes and massive open world are a treat for explorers and fans of chaotic action. However, the game is marred by inconsistent graphics performance, especially on consoles, leading to frame rate drops and occasional texture pop-ins. Additionally, character animations sometimes appear stiff and lack the polish expected from a modern AAA title. While the explosions and destruction effects are spectacular, they often come at the cost of compromising overall graphical fidelity.

Presentation:
The presentation is a mixed bag. On one hand, the game's user interface is intuitive and easy to navigate. However, the narrative presentation feels lackluster and fails to engage players fully. The opening hours struggle to hook players into the plot, making it difficult to invest emotionally in the story. Furthermore, the cutscenes suffer from awkward pacing and lack of emotional depth, leaving players feeling detached from the events unfolding in the game.

Sound:
The audio design complements the explosive nature of the gameplay, with satisfying weapon sounds and powerful explosions. However, the voice acting and dialogue writing fall short of expectations, often feeling cheesy and uninspired. Characters lack depth, and their interactions with the protagonist, Rico Rodriguez, lack meaningful substance. This detracts from the game's attempt to create a compelling narrative and diminishes the overall impact of the story.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is undoubtedly the highlight of the experience, offering a sandbox of destruction and mayhem. Rico's grappling hook and wingsuit combination provides players with a unique and exhilarating way to traverse the vast open world. The freedom to create chaos and use the environment creatively remains a core strength of the series. However, the repetitive mission structure can quickly become tiresome. Side missions and activities often lack variety and depth, leaving players longing for more meaningful and challenging content. Additionally, the AI of enemy NPCs is underwhelming, leading to uninspired combat encounters that become predictable over time.

Story:
The narrative of falls short of its potential. The plot lacks focus and struggles to find a meaningful direction. The primary antagonist is one-dimensional and fails to elicit any real sense of threat or urgency. As a result, players may feel disconnected from the central conflict, impacting their motivation to progress through the story. Furthermore, character development is minimal, making it hard to form genuine connections with the supporting cast. The missed opportunity to build a compelling and engaging narrative is one of the game's most significant drawbacks.

Conclusion:
Avalanche Studios delivers the explosive action and chaotic gameplay the series is known for, but it falls short in other essential aspects. While the graphics showcase stunning environments, performance issues hinder the overall experience. The presentation lacks the necessary polish to engage players, and the story fails to leave a lasting impression. Despite its shortcomings, fans of open-world destruction may still find enjoyment in the game's sandbox experience, but others may feel disappointed by the missed potential and lack of innovation.  I would rate this 6/10.  Mediocre

142889261.review:
Flat out NO!

Firstly... Denuvo.. I don't really understand why there is still this need for DRM ontop of DRM ontop of Client software (like Steam, etc.)... but if that's a problem for you, it's here.

But more importantly, finally trying this game in 2023, 5 years after release... this thing is too buggy and unpolished for anyone to make excuses for it.

Here's a run down of what I actually played.

Mission 1... intro mission. Rico is back to being a barebones nothing with a basic grappling hook and parachute. When you expend primary ammo of a weapon, he just throws that weapon away. The intro mission is almost entirely in a straight line in front of you and up a mountain... yet you are still given constant short distance waypoints to guide you... because clearly you are too stupid to be trusted to get to where you want to go.

Mission 2.... The WALKING mission. Apparently the grappling hook was damaged (I couldn't sit through the whole previous cutscene), so all you do here is find your way on foot over this scrap metal bridge into a jungle rebel base. No combat, no platforming or anything. 100% walking and listening to story dialogie between Rico and the woman over the radio.. until you trigger the next story cutscene.

Mission 3... Still linear "level" gameplay. You are still not allowed to deviate, explore, or enjoy in ANYTHING outside of the missions parameters. Here I had to blow up some objects that were NOT the usual, and clearly identifiable CHAOS structures. I was attacked by a chopper.. grappled onto it and tried to take over, but NO, apparently you are not allowed to control a vehicle yet. So I destroy the chopper, it goes twirling down, and then starts spinning, and spinning... and spinning, slowly grinding its way into the game world's floor. If you still felt somewhat immersed by this point, this sad little glitch would have finally broken you.

And at this point I felt I had seen all that needed to be seen.

New voice actor for Rico. While I am sure he is a talented guy, whoever was directing his acting... was not. You are now playing a Rico that sounds like Pacino's Scarface... Rico Montana... choo know what I mean mang?

And Rico, along with every other bit of the cutscenes and voice acting, is taking himself way too seriously. The "walking mission" cutscene was all heavy drama, but dumbed down for a 12 year old console audience. No jokes, no satire, just drama. Everything about those old D grade action films from the 80's that Just Cause embraced through over the top comedy and bombast... now is exactly as laughable, in a sad way, as the worst of those old action films. When you do hear Rico throw out a quip during gameplay, it still feels forced and more like an action hero one liner that is meant to sound "cool" instead of "we're making fun of this, and ourselves,"

As other neg reviews mention, and are correct.. the feel of the game is off. It's like they tried to port the JC3 framework into a new engine, and while tweaking the physics and general handling, they just gave up half way through the beta and said "F* it, that's good enough."

What I saw in the missions of the world also seemed like the world lacks character. A real shame because that South American jungle vibe was something I was really looking forward to, but it really lacks the sense of "life" that JC 2 and 3 had.

Save yourself the bandwidth and the time and just go replay JC 2 or 3.

this game is a pretty big step backwards from the previous game. in just cause 3 you would liberate cities and bases individually, each one presenting a new challenge and a new reward. the story was great, filled with well written lovable characters and great missions. the bases were all unique, featuring crazy new things. there are bases in huge caves, bases on huge mountains, there was one base in a large crater with rivers running around it. i'm not looking these up, i'm telling them from experience because of how memorable they were to liberate. i cant remember any of the JC4 bases in the same way as JC3, mainly because the liberation system is terrible. you do one lame mission, of which there are only a few different types, and take over one or more entire regions. for whatever reason you decided to remove the pistols, even though they were one of my favourite weapons. the story is easy to forget, and the characters have little personality.
JC3 had:
Mario, the charming guy with the cool shotgun
Sheldon, the selfish, Texas guy with a "corporate" personality.
Dima, the awkward scientist with a good backstory
JC4 had:
girl whose name i actually don't remember, i want to say Myra?
her sister or cousin or something, i don't remember. she runs the black hand.
the hacker. she actually did have a great personality, unlike most characters in the story. i'm pretty sure her name started with an L or a Z. i think it might be Liza.

aside from removing some of the better guns, including pistols, just cause 4 mainly focuses on sandbox features, with the story and liberation being a secondary and mostly optional thing.
while i do admit i love the sandbox abilities and the added features, i am seriously disappointed with the story and the game design. i can easily beat the story in under a day, and be bored most of the time.
JC3 also had cool easter eggs like the rubber ducky jet ski, or being able to go the hidden "boom island" if you travel far enough.

141753243.review:
Such a terrible step-down when comparing the game to Just Cause 3. I come very biased.

The Gameplay:
The controls FEEL terrible. They could've literally copypaste 3's control's one to one and have the game handle itself much better. Something about this game feels very, very off. I can't really put this into words, but i'll describe at like this: In Just Cause 3 when you parachute, wingsuit and grapple the game's world works with you and lets you glide across it smoothly. Here - to me, it feels like you have to fight it to move across. 
The game's world feels very bland to me and doesn't speak much volume as 3 did. feels like a bad redo of Just Cause 2's world and nothing is very unique. 
Explosions feel somehow worse than Just Cause 3 and 2 and the combat is about the same as 3's - though, enemies sometimes have insane aim hitting you with surgery precision in literal mud water or can't do shit and just stand there while you're in front of them.

Graphics: 
I don't know how they messed this up, really. The game again compared to 3's graphics looks TERRIBLE. As typing this will be very painful, I just recommend you see comparisons between 3 and 4, absolutely awful.

Performance: 
I have an RTX 3060Ti paired with an i7 12700f with 16Gb of 3200Mhz RAM.
This is by no means a top-notch setup, but it is well beyond to at least allow the game to run at 1440p, 120-100 FPS. But I can't, not at least at a steady 100. There's way too much stuttering and random FPS drops. The game slows to a crawl of 70-50 FPS at big fights, when shooting an RPG (I honestly don't know why) and some more random shit. Just Cause 3 never really had an issue for me, but maybe my PC is weird. 

And finally, the story: It's terrible.
The games takes itself way too seriously and most characters are completely forgettable and unfunny. step down from 3's action-comedy style story, It doesn't let you get as attached to characters here, the likes of which, for example, Mario (my mannn) from 3.
There aren't any funny tropes to characters that captivate you from the start or anything interesting really. Honestly, skip the story when playing.

Overall, though - the game is fun at it's core. It is just a huge step-down from 3 and If you don't have the money, don't buy this game and get 3 now instead, as when it is on sale, it's like 5-11 dollars.

141584955.review:
[h1] Not nearly as bad as mixed reviews make it seem [/h1]

Downgrades from JC3:
-there are no bases or outposts that you can complete without leaving vehicle, you will always be forced to do some objectives on foot. Which is a downgrade for me because I loved doing helicopter assaults and bomber runs in JC3
-collision physics are definitely more glitchy. The way your helicopter recoils from hitting a drone or another helicopter, or the way ground vehicles stumble over debris and invisible road bumps can get a bit annoying
-texture quality up close seems worse. In engine cutscenes left me wondering what happened to the texture quality since JC3. 

Upgrades:
+Biodiversity of the map. Map is separated into 4 very distinct biomes. They look great from afar. More diverse than Medici.
+We're back into more serious tone of the narrative. Characters are likeable and not exaggerated, story feels more personal despite not being set in MC's home.
+Thematically, Army of Chaos is significant improvement over rebels. They start off with 1 stronghold against Black Hand, establish frontlines, and as their numbers grow and you secure more footholds in other regions - those frontlines move and increase in numbers. There's also a cool dynamic in how you don't just gain squads by leveling up and lose them to move frontlines. When moving into a region reduces the number of frontlines - you free up the squads for other uses.
+Combat feels more balanced, varied and responsive. Balanced because with just 2 guns of any category and no any-ammo gunlockers everywhere - you scavenge for weapons and ammo more, like we were in JC2. Varied because most guns have alternative fire mode. Responsive because there is a satisfying sound effect for nailing headshots which doesn't leave you wondering whether you should double tap or move on to next target.
+Enemy has jets and actually uses them to counter your aerial vehicles. They no longer feel like just a set piece of airbases. 
+Challenges are not nearly as crucial for unlocking all the tools, nor are they as time consuming. You get all the aerial moves you had to unlock with gears in JC3 by default, and generally about a 1/3 of all the challenges is needed to unlock all the non-crucial stuff. Do take time for 40 wingsuit challenges tho, these give you 3 charges of rockets to your jet wingsuit.

Overall, worthy addition to the franchise. Hope the mixed reception doesn't ruin the chances of the franchise continuing. Hopefully with less technical issues next time. I generally approve the direction of gameplay and narrative Avalanche took with JC4.

141411746.review:
Woah okay, so I got this game along with the other 3 just cause games and I've played through them all until I reached this title. Its bad, its really bad.

Please note I've only played this game for like 50 minutes, and normally I dont think reviews are too valid until you've beaten the game but I honestly dont feel like wasting my time. I also feel like the fact that I was able to construct a list of complaints this long and detailed within 50 minutes speaks to the inherently flawed game design and may save some people from wasting their time and money on a terrible product.

Its a direct downgrade from just cause 3 in mechanics, story, characters, gameplay, objectives and visuals from the previous title.

Just cause 2 was pretty bad in my opinion, and it feels like the guy who made JC2 got put back in charge after JC3. Ammo restraints are back, I never have bullets. They added drone enemies, which while they existed in JC3 they were only in certain areas and they werent that many of them. Now they're everywhere, very small, very fast and they're super tanky, (which exacerbates the ammo problem). They tied grenades to the guns and removed your infinite bavarium C4 charges. Weapon dumps are far more limited, they arent clearly marked and they mostly carry one or two weapons. They removed the ability to carry 3 weapons at least as far as I was in the game you could only carry 2- which meant once again you had to choose between rocket launchers and anti personnel items. Vehicles have ammo now... which .... why, and now objective markers are hidden behind some sort of augmented reality contact lens. 

The Chaos system is back, WHY IS IT BACK?!? IT THE WORST SYSTEM EVER! YOU HAD IT JUST CAUSE DEVS! YOU'D FIGURED OUT THE KEY TO SATISFYING SIDE CONTENT IN 3 WHY DID YOU BRING SUCH A TERRIBLE SYSTEM FROM 2? It existed in 3 to an extent but it wasnt intrusive. It went hand in hand with the outpost conquest system so most of the time I didnt even notice it was there. In short the main game progress is blocked until you cause enough "chaos" which basically means until you've blown up a enough random red objects, or completed side objectives youre effectively stuck. In this game its tied to the frontline  mechanic which was kind of cool but since it was tied to the tedious side objectives rather than the actual frontline combat it was unsatisfying. Outpost are no longer conquered by destruction, in fact destruction does nothing except generate chaos, the destroyed objects even respawn so your impact on the world is negligible.

Speaking of red objects, what happened to the destruction dynamics? The ball shaped fuel containers dont explode any more, they sparkle with blue energy now, the radio towers break into chucks like they were built with legos instead of falling over all cool like they did in 3, red objectives have overall less explosions, things just seem to spark now instead of explode.
While we're on the topic of objectives, the whole "hack the computer" thing, where if you get shot during the 15 seconds of hacking you get stopped and have to start over is OBJECTIVELY a bad mechanic. I never almost never use the word objectively - you'll always be able to find someone who like something but that doesnt apply here, so please allow me to explain. A person who is playing this game has paid money to play the game, as a mechanic  the hacking system consists of pressing a button and then not playing the game while you wait for it to complete. Whats more the completion of this objective has very little to do with skill or strategy, since even if you kill all nearby enemies, if you have any heat level at all (which you will since these hacking objectives are placed within enemy bases) the game can spawn an enemy and shoot you within those 15 seconds. Therefore this mechanic does not reward intelligent gameplay, it does not reward skilled gameplay, by definition it is not gameplay in and of itself since the player has no agency or input during the 15 second hacking time, thus I assert that this mechanic is objectively bad. Just a heads up, it looks like a pretty core mechanic as well since In the roughly 50 minutes of gameplay I experienced I did this 5 times. 

Moving on... Story - I dont care, I reallllllllllly dont care, but as far as I can tell these cut scenes are unskippable. Rico was an agency operative in the first 3 games and he was having some issues with them in 3, which I didnt really understand since Rico was doing good work for the agency in all the games and was still doing stuff for Sheldon in 3, but now he's no longer with the agency, I guess, and he's investigating a super weapon his father built........ what? The writers didnt think to mention in the first three games that Rico's father built super weapons? Also I thought JC3 said that his parents were assassinated when he was a kid, he's like 40 now, if this weapons been around for 30-ish years why is it only now a problem. I paid attention to the main plot of the games in 1-3, based on what was disclosed in those games this makes no sense, if it was explained elsewhere thats just bad writing. As it is the jump from 3 to 4 has already pulled me out of any sort of emotional investment you created in 3 since theyre such different characters. He's also teamed up with some random woman and the game waits all of 5 minutes before trying to pull some starwars plot twist stuff, (oh my god I dont care). Then they're like okay - time to overthrow the government.................................. Dude what? The "bad guys" havent even done anything yet except try to kill you when you attacked their military base unprovoked. Uhhh yeah, Rico is terrorist in this one.
Speaking of Rico what happened to his character? He was this charming fun loving and playful dude in 3 but in  4 he's this grungy edgy guy, like the most bland main character from some sort of b-tier action movie.

Graphics.......... this looks like a generational downgrade from 3 and I dont know why, also the mandatory cutscenes were locked at like 20 frames per second while the game ran at like 90 FPS, so those scenes were really choppy.

Some side notes, before I leave, the physics in this feel even floatier than before which I personally didnt like, it took any sort of skill out of grappling hook traversal, the wing suit felt slower, and despite my complaint about less explosions earlier the red barrels in this are way too fragile, I brushed one in the first allied settlement you access and it exploded. I didnt shoot it and I wasnt being shot at, it just barely fell over and blew up. Also the first mission where you dont have your grappling hook, it wants you to cross a bridge, there are three paths but it just mission fails you unless you take the one it wants, and it doesnt give you any sort of indication which one is the right path, it just has a marker on the other side of the bridge, I dont know how much they do this later, but since just cause has traditionally been a "find your own solution" sort of game I was pretty miffed to be punished for finding an alternate solution. 

Seriously if you're looking for a Just Cause game, go play 3.

this game is a pretty big step backwards from the previous game. in just cause 3 you would liberate cities and bases individually, each one presenting a new challenge and a new reward. the story was great, filled with well written lovable characters and great missions. the bases were all unique, featuring crazy new things. there are bases in huge caves, bases on huge mountains, there was one base in a large crater with rivers running around it. i'm not looking these up, i'm telling them from experience because of how memorable they were to liberate. i cant remember any of the JC4 bases in the same way as JC3, mainly because the liberation system is terrible. you do one lame mission, of which there are only a few different types, and take over one or more entire regions. for whatever reason you decided to remove the pistols, even though they were one of my favourite weapons. the story is easy to forget, and the characters have little personality.
JC3 had:
Mario, the charming guy with the cool shotgun
Sheldon, the selfish, Texas guy with a "corporate" personality.
Dima, the awkward scientist with a good backstory
JC4 had:
girl whose name i actually don't remember, i want to say Myra?
her sister or cousin or something, i don't remember. she runs the black hand.
the hacker. she actually did have a great personality, unlike most characters in the story. i'm pretty sure her name started with an L or a Z. i think it might be Liza.

aside from removing some of the better guns, including pistols, just cause 4 mainly focuses on sandbox features, with the story and liberation being a secondary and mostly optional thing.

The game isn't polished and I don't think it's worth playing, unless you want to appreciate Just Cause 3 even more.

139475923.review:
My one thought is a confusing one to me; "What is this?"

Many people seem to complain about Just Cause 4 in relation to Just Cause 3, but I think that is just rose tinted glasses talking. 

All of the Just Cause games have sickening amounts of pop in. Turn around and new enemies have, somehow, manifested from thin air. This is bad enough on foot, constantly having to mow down yet more cannon fodder from this "elite private army." 

Take to the seas? Turn the camera and Bam! A new enemy naval squadron has somehow just deployed from that shallow inlet they couldn't possibly have come from. The air is even worse, since a constant stream of choppers, jets and drones will just fly at you. 

Make no mistake, I like challenge, but I'm serious. It. Is. Constant. Game development like that just suggests that the maker couldn't be bothered with meaningless stuff, like challenging enemies, so they just lazily threw in the towel and set them to constant respawn. It's stone cold disgusting.

Another thing that bugged me was the enemy A.I., simultaneously hyper capable and suicidal. How do I mean? Well, suicidal in that those constant enemy air units will happily commit aeronautical seppuku right into your tail fin, killing the both of you. "It killed you, right? So it's a good challenge." I know someone will think that and they are stupid. A good challenge is something that I can actually counter, which I can't if the entire enemy air force is willing to kamikaze me.

Also, for hyper capable, every enemy sniper is ridiculously, superhumanly skilled. Forget that garbage you see in movies where people just rack up headshots as soon as the enemy comes in view, shooting is hard. Shooting a target zipping along in a wingsuit, while you are in a helicopter bobbing around, should be outright impossible, but I guess that shows what I know, since every shooter can slot one in your dome 9 times out of 10 in that situation, so I guess I just need to git gud.

Even after all of that, what made me ragequit and uninstall the game this go round was when I shot at an enemy tank, whereupon it flew into the air. As it was cartwheeling around at about 150 feet above me it, and this is real, instakilled my own tank with an immaculate shot. I already was, at best, only mildly amused with the game, but if the makers are just going to give the enemies aimbots, why should I play?

The missions, while I think were more varied than in Just Cause 3's one-two punch of either blow stuff up or drive someplace, were still rather dull. The story was bland. Yet another dictator needs to get taken down. Wow. Never would've seen that coming. The characters in the story were, while not grating or offensive, well...how do I put this...they were too "quirky and upbeat" for a gaggle of people who should've been terrorized and victimized for years by a tyrant and his private army.

If there is something good to say, the landscape was beautiful. That may not sound like much, but I liked the view of Solis whether I was driving, sailing, wingsuiting, etc. Looks like a neat place to visit when there isn't a war on. Speaking of war, I also liked the fact that there were outright warzones on the borders of regions controlled by the good guys and bad. That was a slick touch, even having the ground scorched and pockmarked with damage. Gorgeous, gorgeous, devastation.

Ultimately, though, visuals aren't enough. Absurd A.I. alongside dull missions and a bland story mean that, no. I can't recommend it to anyone.

139166910.review:
I started this game with low expectations due to the reviews and its reputation gained. However, as I continued playing; I started unexpectedly enjoying the game as much as JC2 and JC3. I disregarded its bad reputation and saw it in a new light. It is a Just Cause game that spins freshness in the franchise, especially coming out of JC3 (conquering all the settlements that felt similar to another). Of course I do not expect its different take on the gameplay loop to carry on to the 5th game. Conversely, I hope that a lot of its good parts carry over to the 5th game while maintaining the classic JC gameplay loop.

Coming out of JC3, what I desired was a diverse sandbox with variety of terrain types and biomes. Although you could say JC3 mastered the gameplay loop, what it didn't master was keeping the players freshened up when exploring different areas. Essentially, the problem from JC3 was the lack of diversity in the buildings and landscapes if you were to compare to JC2. JC4 solved that problem, while focusing (although a gimmick) on the climate and its weather. The story is also involved around manmade natural disasters from weather. I believe the environment you play in is more important than graphics (in which I have no problems with). I see it as an art direction as it also envelops the world with vibrancy.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/517630/Just_Cause_4_Reloaded/#
Now, was the gameplay loop for JC4 executed well? In my opinion, it gave convenience to conquering the lands instead of finding each location and trying to find the last part to blow up (addicting, although got tiring at the end when trying to complete all settlements). It fulfilled my desire to the do the challenges to upgrade (although not as impressive as JC3). In a sense, the game was amazing with delivering to my desires and cravings at that time. I understand the backlash, in some people's eyes, the game downgraded in many ways. But as a gamer with an independent mind and differing opinion, I love this game to death.

137333525.review:
Just Cause 4 provides more chaotic mayhem as expected from a game in the Just Cause franchise, but a lot of ups and downs in gameplay and presentation make this game a major disappointment. 4/10
Total size on my hard-drive: 69.5 GB

+ Gun-play is significantly improved. Headshots are a lot easier.
+ Grapple options are greatly expanded, allowing for new levels of creativity
+ The single benefit of the sub-par graphics is that load times are VERY fast (especially compared to Just Cause 3).
+ The story is a great continuation from Just Cause 3's story.
+ Lots of fast-travel points
+ Solis is large and laid out well

+ /- Interesting system of the Rebellion Frontline and needing cause chaos to recruit more rebels to take more areas. Problem is, it devolves into repeated base-takeover missions, with no variation.
+/- Just Cause games are built on using the same types of missions over and over in different settings. Just Cause 4 doesn't buck the trend.

- - Mounted guns are no longer detachable. What the actual f--k?
- No health indicator
- Checkpoint saving only.
- I suspect it still has Denuvo (the game exe is 274 MB)
- No weapon or vehicle upgrades (there are a lot of weapons and vehicles to choose from, but no upgrade system)
- No "destruction tally / total" for settlements. Destructible objects reset periodically (sometimes when loading a save). You can endlessly destroy stuff every time you boot the game, but a major feeling of progression is lost. 
- No timer on "delivery events" - so what's the point? Drive from point A to point B at the speed of a bicycle? Come on.
- Stunt challenges now frequently require specific vehicles.
- Stunt challenges don't appear in the game world unless you've deliberately tracked them from the map by clicking on them. (you'll be visiting the map a lot)
- Graphics are a major disappointment. I'm firmly in the "good enough" camp when it comes to graphics, but compared to how stunning Just Cause 2 and Just Cause 3 were when they launched, Just Cause 4 is a major step backwards with major glitches with anti-aliasing and ambient occlusion. Hair is is bugged as well, resulting in a weird shimmer on hair textures. Textures in general are low-res (I played at 3440x1440). Even explosions look worse than previous games (and aren't as large, either). Where are the graphics from the pre-release trailers that said "captured in-engine"? Those graphics look glorious. They're no-where to be found in the actual game.
- [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2967538421]Texture stream-in[/url] is a major problem (JC4 was installed on an SSD)
- Pre-rendered cutscenes are a pixelated 720p mess. Media codecs have advanced significantly. Great picture quality in a small file size was very doable in 2018 when Just Cause 4 launched. There's no excuse for this.
- Occasional crashing when attempting to fast-travel (four times in 27 hours)
- Extended helicopter rampages are impossible now. Numerous enemy helicopters spawn immediately (not a problem) and will kill themselves and you by flying into you if they can't kill you immediately (that's a problem).
- a very intricate supply drop system is made pointless by all the weapon cases that are EVERYWHERE
- "ghost spawns" are frequent and annoying (enemies are invisible, but can still shoot you)
- Tanks, helicopters, planes etc. now have a finite amount of ammo. So even if you survive the numerous suiciding enemies, your time in a tank or helicopter will be artificially limited. ("But muh realism!" - it's a game, it's supposed to be fun)
- "defend the transmitter" side-missions are bulls--t. You'll spend way to much time re-doing them because there's an enemy you can't see / hit from the provided turret / mounted gun. (This "hidden" enemy will destroy the transmitter, requiring a re-start of the mission.)
- Debris collision physics are buggy. Debris frequently gets stuck under vehicles (even tanks) causing severe handling issues.
- Vehicle handling is as bad as it was in Just Cause 3. No improvement whatsoever.
- Gabriela Morales, hyped in the promotional material as a major villain, is only seen twice: the opening mission and the final mission.

137194513.review:
Just Cause 4, the latest addition to the Just Cause franchise, fails to impress with its lack of innovation and identical gameplay to its predecessor, Just Cause 3. Despite being marketed as a brand new game, Just Cause 4 feels like nothing more than a cheap knock-off of the previous game, with only a handful of improvements that do little to justify its existence as a separate title.

The improvements in Just Cause 4, such as the inclusion of extreme weather conditions and new gadgets, do little to add to the overall experience. The weather effects are nothing more than a novelty, and the gadgets are more of the same old tools that players have been using in the previous games with little additions. The lack of any significant improvements or innovations leaves players wondering why they should even bother with this game when they could just stick to playing Just Cause 3.

In conclusion, Just Cause 4 is a lackluster addition to the Just Cause franchise that fails to live up to the expectations set by its predecessor. The game feels like a cash grab, with minimal changes to the gameplay and a lack of any meaningful improvements. Save your money and stick to Just Cause 3 if you're looking for a fun and engaging open-world experience.

137078511.review:
tl;dr - game is "good" but in a mindless way, dont go in expecting a highly polished product. use some mods to make the game less aggravating because theres no difficulty choices; rico is superman anyway so may as well make him stronger. pick it up on sale. 

There are certain expectations to be set with Just Cause 4 that I feel are particularly important with regards to fully enjoying it.

(1) This is a prime example of a "AA" game, or, if you will, a "junk food game". It's not explicitely *good* per se, the story is utterly forgettable and meaningless, but the gameplay is just downright fun and lets you switch your brain off whilst you look at pretty explosions and making the baddies fly away into the sky with big oversized balloons. If you're coming to this game expecting anything more than a ps2-grade game where the loop is effectively "go to this place, shoot the baddies, blow up these things, interact with this thing, repeat", you're probably not going to have a great time of it.

(2, or 1b) this game is janky as balls, man. object clipping is frequent. it's incredibly easy to get Rico stuck in some geometry for a short moment. The wingsuiting tech is weird and sometimes will let you easily turn whilst it wont other times. All adds to the charm but it can lead to frustration, especially when dealing with a lot of enemies in an area, hence this suggestion...

(3) install a mod loader (Ashen is a good one since it just works by letting you press play in steam) and install a couple of mods that make you more overpowered (always fun, and rico is effectively meant to be superman lets be honest here) and/or a mod that completely removes the heat/wanted system. You might think, oh, well, that removes all the challenge from the game doesnt it? and yeah, it kinda does, but for me I found battling both the game's jankiness AND the hoardes of enemies to be extremely frustrating especially on the games various timed missions. Plus it makes all the bad guys just stand around awkwardly like they forgot why they just spawned in in the first place, which is always funny.

with all that said, its been a lovely little wind down game to muck about in whilst having some videos on in the background. i enjoy games where i basically have just a checklist of things to do that i can slowly chip away at bit by bit and this game is p much nothing but that. as for if its better than jc3 or 2? ehhh that's entirely subjective frankly, but for me this game runs better than those two and it doesnt have the mind numbing repetitiveness of jc3 wherein liberating every town was the exact same process every single time with the exact same objectives every single time.

bought the complete edition for $11 on G2A because from what I remembered in 2018 it was ass, looked like ass, and ran like ass. This was back when I played console.

decided to give it another try after beating JC3 again, somehow max graphics settings looks worse than PS4 did back in 2018, and console doesn't even let you adjust graphics. keep in mind I played on PS4 before the spring "improvement" update in 2019. As far as I'm concerned the spring update was scarcely an improvement, the only good thing they added Rico being able to destroy railway bridges and, from what I remember in 2018, finally being able to destroy cement bridges which should have been a feature on release due to it already being a feature in 3. 

What's even more astonishing is this game doesn't even support water tessellation despite it actually being a graphical feature you can toggle. This game actually looks worse than JC3 in almost every way, driving vehicles and flying feels worse than 3, and somehow they fucked up motorcycles more than 3, when JC3 already severely downgraded motorcycle movement from JC2. The main story is... okay at best. they took out liberating settlements and the new system felt shitty in 2018 and it still does in 2023, however the DLC narratives are probably about as good as the story a piece of toilet paper has after you wipe your ass with it. The cherry on top of this shit cake is how horrible the rebel's colour scheme for vehicles are, From JC1-JC3 I've enjoyed every factions colour schemes for vehicles but here, only the black hand prevail in fashion. For these rebels look like a toddler just figured out that you can use chalk on a sidewalk.

 I hope to god if they ever make a 5th just cause that avalanche is banned from touching the series ever again and a different, more stable, engine is used. Though honestly, I don't see that happening, sadly triple A companies have just been a massive let down of shit cash grabs and micro-transactions for about the last decade it feels like, in my opinion to anyone casually scrolling through this if you're looking to buy, don't. Save your money for something worth it, or at the very least get it when/if it's on sale or even just free, because this game is the worst one out of the four.

136824444.review:
I tried really hard to not judge this game based on the success of the other games. And I would like to think i did a pretty good job of that. The game at its core is similar to the other ones, blow shit up complete quests etc etc. 

BUT the things you will interact  with to actually play and enjoy the game, the menus, the story, the dialogue, driving vehicles, all feel very rushed.

Cutscenes are super short and poorly written, the voice acting feels like they used the wrong filter for the audio. AND DONT EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THE MENUS. Playing on PC you are forced to use the enter keys, backspace and the arrow keys to navigate. You cant just click on stuff. AND WHY ON GODS GREEN EARTH IS THE NUMBER 1 KEY, THE KEY YOU USE IN LITERALLY EVERY OTHER GAME TO SWAP WEAPONS WITH... WHY IS IT THE MENU BUTTON!

Edit: having finally beaten the game this review doesnt change much and goes further to note that vehicle physics are awful. Vehicles don't have ANY traction off road. You grind to a halt and cant accelerate or steer for garbage. 
And on more than one occasion parts of the environment will get stuck inside of vehicles and auto detonate them. sometimes in missions where you need to protect the vehicle you can do nothing more than helplessly watch as the health bar plummets towards zero.

as a further note, the world is large and empty. its fast travel here, wing-suit or fly (because driving is RARELY an option) to the location do a quest and rinse repeat. There are way to many challenges outside of missions don't even bother collecting them all. its simply not worth the headache.

In terms of combat encounters, they all feel either way to easy or way to hard, there is little in between. which is really unfortunate due to the fact the guns and gun play feel pretty alright. 

I'm unsure of what kind of substance these developers were smoking but the execution and design of this game falls flat in every turn.

The only thing I can say that is positive about this is the gun play feels alright. BUT  even that takes a hit in some missions where you simply need to be better to have a victory. 

overall do not buy this game for anything more than 10 bucks. and go in with little in expectations. I really hope the devs IF they make a JC5 learn what makes a good game and what made this one so pitiful.

136261349.review:
This is my honest view on Just Cause 4 Complete Edition. Both the good and the bad.

Firstly, I've waited a long time before choosing to buy this game. I've watched some many videos and read reviews and opinions. I've done my best to keep my feelings unbiased as well. 

I'd also like to say that I can see the developers tried to go in a new direction and also had good intentions. I can see in some areas they really did put effort in. But their approach and design choices were not very good overall and this has left me disappointed in the game. However there is good too and I do not feel it's right to simply bash a game and pretend there isn't anything good about it IF there is good.So here is my review.

- The world is beautifully designed. I feel like it's an improvement over the 3rd in some ways. Not in every way. But definitely some prettier things to see overall. Graphically, I am not impressed overall. But it's alright. However there ARE some eyesores particularly with the water both ocean and river. 

- Gameplay wise I found that some steps were taken forward. But I am sad to say that many seem to have been taken back. 

I like the challenge of the combat with the enemies. It's got some fun to it however I do feel it could have benefited from further balancing. Sometimes missions and general gameplay get a bit too unfair. And more annoying rather than fun.

The missions are too repetitive and tedious. I am not a fan of it and honestly I think they could have done better than the same defend this, flip these switches, destroy these generators and so on. 

I hate that there is no longer a real reason to destroy all the "red objects" and thus liberate the locations. This mechanic was genuinely a favorite of mine and they removed it.

The destruction feels less in this one and whilst I've found some new things to destroy, overall, it feels less. Even bridges can no longer be destroyed which is quite saddening honestly.. I enjoyed that feature.. 

It seems the developers have tried to turn Just Cause 4 into a more serious game rather than sticking to it's random fun and silly factor. Its very clear when you look at the storyline aspect. However their attempt to make a good story falls short. I can see they tried, but I felt that up to the point I played, that it lacked real emotion. It wasn't well thought out in my opinion and in some ways seemed sort of rushed. As if they threw random ideas into it and tried to piece it together.  They should have rather stuck to focusing more on the gameplay. I can tell just from the early parts of the storyline that it's not something that will truly grip me. However I can see they had the right idea. But just poorly executed. 

The UI is genuinely terrible. I honestly find it annoying. The drops for weapons/items/vehicles is just absolutely dreadful to to use. One pilot for one item, must wait and all that nonsense.. I get you wanted to go for realism. But gosh... I really honestly don't know what they were thinking with this design choice. It's really the worst I've ever encountered in a game and I mean it.. And the same goes for the UI. The map, the changing of the grappling hook stuff including upgrading of features etc. Just Cause 3 did this very well. But 4 just really failed in pretty much every way here..

Bug wise/crashes. Gosh crashes,freezes and all. I am utterly disappointed. Also, don't buy this if you're on Windows 7. Because despite the store page saying the minimum requirements is windows 7 SP1, you're going to have issues playing it. LOTS of freezing, LOTS of crashes. And overall, unplayable. You need to at least be on windows 10. But the thing is, there is a STILL a chance you're gonna have the same problems unfortunately... So beware.. Just take a look at the tech support section on the Steam Forums and you'll see for yourself just how bad it really is. I can only play this properly on 10 or higher.

The Wingsuit is still really nice but I found they had made some changes in it's handling. I find JC3 to do things better. If one has the DLC for the jetpack addon, it really is far more satisfying to use. It feels (and am pretty sure it is) faster than JC3 and I found myself really having fun just exploring the world with it. The weapons on it, I found it much easier to use the rockets to hit my target than in JC3 and it is overall, fairly satisfying. They did a good job on this part.

The car chases whilst you're on a vehicle felt faster in missions which I enjoyed as well. It felt nice and more action packed in some ways. This I feel was a good improvement. So plus 1 to them.

Fun factor wise, I struggled to enjoy the game overall. The vehicles, the weapons etc.. They had the right idea and direction in their minds. But again, fell short/executed it all poorly.

The extreme weather was an interesting concept. But it doesn't feel like a selling point for me to be honest. 

In a nutshell. This game has a lot of disappointments. However there IS good in it. There IS fun to be had. And I've seen plenty reviews and so on where people really did enjoy themselves. But for me, I can't personally recommend the game. I feel it's taken too many steps backwards on what makes Just Cause fun and enjoyable. The steps taken forward don't make up for the steps taken back and so it leaves me feeling bored and frustrated rather than happy and immersed.

I would honestly rather recommend buying Just Cause 3 or even Just Cause 2. They live up to the franchise and offer more fun. However if you can get this game on sale for 50-75% off, then I'd say get it. It does offer some fun and it's not a complete failure. But I can't say it's not worth full price and nor can I justify paying the full price. It has some wonderful aspects. But overall, it's a no for me.

136146930.review:
This game really isn't good, there's some fun to be had here but overall it's just very meh. The game is incredibly easy, Rico can take like 20 gunshots before dying and your health regenerates incredibly quickly, over my 9 hours with the game, I died once, maybe twice. There is no challenge to the core combat loop, with challenge only coming from annoying mission objectives.

Instead of the satisfying chaos system from Just Cause 2 where every outpost and town can be cleared with a fun 100 percent system, we get a generic leveling system that feels like it's just from Assassin's Creed or Horizon ZD. Blowing up stuff is still fun but it lacks the strong backing of the chaos system and generally just feels kinda hollow.

The main missions feel drawn out and uninspired. A lot of the missions will have you guiding some incredibly stupid NPCs out of a military base, the AI for both friendlies and enemies is incredibly stupid, it's especially annoying in missions when friendlies you rely on to complete mission objectives just don't act how you'd expect them to, randomly stopping for like 30 seconds or getting stuck on a random wall. NPCs will not die, they have an insane amount of health and can probably take hundreds of bullets before dying, but the missions are still somehow challenging because the AI will constantly just break. Also, instead of just escorting one group of NPCs to the exit of the facility, you have to escort 3 groups one by one and it takes fucking forever, it's so boring.

There are also boring hacking quests where you kinda just stand near a computer waiting for it to download data or something while shooting at enemies.

The map feels kinda lifeless, JC2 had a big central city that felt alive plus lots of smaller villages, and a lot of military bases 
that felt at least a little different from one another. In this game, there is one sort of bigger city that is still very small with almost nothing to do in it, all the smaller towns have nothing to do in them, nothing to blow up and usually no enemies to fight and all the military bases feel incredibly similar just being giant concrete blocks that are really boring to look at. The world just doesn't feel alive, there's no reason to ever visit different areas in the game that aren't military bases.

This game has Denuvo which I hate, Denuvo should be removed from JC3 and 4, I've been blocked from playing this game because it "couldn't connect to the servers", meaning I'm being punished for legally owning this game. Squeenix needs to remove Denuvo from this.

There is some dumb fun to be had here, the combat can be fun despite having 0 challenge and blowing stuff up can be a cool looking spectacle even if I don't really have any motivation to be blowing things up aside from just the fun sparks and fire. The traversal can also be fun, wing-suiting and parachuting around is fun, the grappling hook feels good, it feels good to use the traversal mechanics well to get around the map quickly.

Overall, there is some fun here and you might want to get the game for a very discounted price, but I'd recommend playing Just Cause 2 over this game because the world feels more alive, JC2 doesn't have Denuvo DRM/can always be played offline, and blowing stuff up is more satisfying in JC2 because of the Chaos system.
