Sometimes you press Return (make me take my hand off the mouse?), sometimes backspace -- never the Escape key BTW -- but other times you can't press enter on something already selected, you have to click on it.  And equipping things sometimes means leaving the "game" entirely and going to "Options" (like Graphics/Controls/etc options). ?  Finding things is the main challenge.
Then for some reason they have you watch cutscenes of your character doing the truly interesting and exciting stuff that's relevant for the plot. Why not let us PLAY OUT the parts of the plot that actually matter? 

5 hours in, I have a whole open world to blow up and hundreds missions to complete, but...meh?  I don't wanna.

134709984.review:
Just finished this game and immediately uninstalled it, not because the ending was especially horrible (it's a stinker though), but just because I'm completely sick of playing it. The thing that made its predecessor Just Cause 3 fun is taking over military bases by just blowing the shit out of them with missiles and gradually taking them apart one petrol storage container at a time, like eating a large explosive meal that leaves you very satisfied. 

What they decided to do for this one is to have the bases be the same 4-5 mini-missions spread across about 30 bases. what these base missions have in common are that they are all uniformly bland, boring, and irritating all in their own unique ways, and most require just standing at a console and doing "hacking" for 5 minutes while you shoot the dull weapons at the dull enemies. It's such a baffling design decision, because they have all the explosive tanks and whatever scattered around, but destroying them is more or less a waste of ammo apart from seeing the pretty explosions, they don't progress the missions. Even Just cause 2 had that and just cause 2 is fucking tedious to take over bases in. 

The story is bland, and the characters are about as boring as revolutionary war leaders could possibly be. The humour is hit and miss but mostly miss (and to be honest maybe I was just in a good mood when it "hit"). Just cause is not a game you go to for a good story anyway but not one of these bland-as-a-cement-sandwich moon-faced cretins has a quarter of, for example, Dimah Al-Masri's personality.

So we have poor gameplay, ignorable story, and all the good gameplay elements are transplanted from JC3, what do I LIKE about this game? 

The setting! The map is absolutely beautiful, huge, and varied like just cause 2, only with better traversal. For some reason they made the cars all as fast as the bavarium supercar from 3 to push it towards making driving a thing that anyone would ever want to do in a game where you have a rocket powered wingsuit (spoilers: I never used cars in this game apart from in missions). And I like that they made the cars fast, I like that they have Jets and planes and helicopters absolutely everywhere, it's almost like half of avalanche knew what kind of game they were making. Just Cause 4's map with Just Cause 3's mechanics would be a marvellous game. If only the mission designers had ever played a GAME before, it might actually be a fun to liberate however many bases and play through the missions, but instead they went for "Breaker box breaker box breaker box hack the terminal destroy the generators defend the satellite dish drive the fucking explosive cars in to the river (because god forbid anything explode in this just cause game) et fucking cetera.

It's an exhausting mess of a game to play through, and the only times I felt like I was having fun were outside of missions, just messing about in the sandbox. They give you like thruster and balloon grappling hooks for some reason, probably so they could put it in the trailer, and apart from the missions where they introduced them I NEVER used them for the entire game, it's like a fun thing to have I guess? Maybe I wasn't creative enough? I don't think it would've saved this from being a slog though.

TLDR: Listen to the other hundreds of reviews that say to get just cause 3 instead, the whole thing plus DLC is usually less than a tenner on steam sales.

134566888.review:
Should you buy this? Maybe

If you love guarding missions, or missions that force you to stay in one place while NPCs "hack" systems while enemies pop in out of nowhere and attack you from all sides then buy this game. If you hated JC2 or JC3's more free flowing game play and wished that missions were absolutely required to take over an enemy facility then you will love this game. If you love needlessly complex systems that make game play frustrating while trying to deal with a chaotic game then you will love this game. If you love how enemy units would spawn in out of nowhere to attack you then you will love this game.
If the above sounds great, then buy the game now and ignore what I say below.

The good things from this game. I loved feeling like there was an actual revolution going on. Having revolutionaries join in the fight was nice. It really felt like you were fighting a battle to free people. The past games felt like a solo war with the occasional battle with incompetent NPCs that I largely ignored. As cool as this is, it just becomes background noise after a while.

I like that there are weapons with so many different neat features. The gun that turns into a shielded turret and the guns with various explosive weapons. They are kind of fun. But I also miss having separate grenades and various explosive weapons.

The really big, annoying thing is the missions. I loved the free flowing nature of the previous games. I could approach capturing the map however I pleased. Now I have to perform missions to capture virtually every part of the map. I hated having to complete missions in JC2&3, but I did them when I had to. Missions are a major part of JC4.
You have to protect someone or something while waves of enemies swarm you or travel around activating things. There is some variations, but they are not terribly fun.

I miss having the supply drop available. Along with many of the things from JC3. The mechs and jet suite were fun. Yes, you can get them as overpriced DLC, but I won't. It is not a fun enough game to warrant buying it, at least at full price.

Long story short, am I happy with the game? I know that I am not enjoying it as much as JC2 or JC3. I have played 6 hours, and I am honestly getting tired of it already. It has some innovative and interesting things added to it. I wish that they would mix the good from the earlier games with the good from this one for future games. We will see if they do.

If you are going to buy it, buy it on sale. I don't recommend buying it at full price. If you love the series, then try it. If you are looking to get into it then buy JC2 or JC3, they are more fun.

133885840.review:
Before I started playing Just Cause 4 (which I’ll be referring to as JC or JC4 throughout this review), I knew very little about the game or the franchise. My knowledge was simply that this was a third-person open-world game with a massive map, lots of side quests, and a reactive and interactive environment (i.e. everything blows up).

I’ve heard that a lot of the fun involved in grappling yourself around the world and blowing stuff - which to be honest, was more than enough for me. Immediately prior to Just Cause, I played three first-person games (Superliminal, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and Deus Ex: Mankind Divided), two of them with long run times and I was ready for a break from that perspective.

As the game was installing, I googled about the JC’s franchise plot to see if I needed any catching p before booting the game, but Reddit assured me the plot for each JC game is independent of each other, so with that in mind, I finally clicked “Play”.

After a short introduction where not much is said, done or explained, we’re in control of Rico Rodriguez. There is probably more here to dig into if you’ve played the other games in the franchise, but I did not get much information out of this short intro. Before you realize it, you’re controlling the main character.

And then I started pressing random buttons (since the game doesn’t give you a lot of hints of what does what). Shot a grenade, fired some shots, jumped, reloaded, and then I finally found RB and grappled myself to the nearest wall. Then I grappled myself to a tower nearby, and then to the top of another wall, and suddenly I was parachuting across a valley. In 15 seconds I had covered an insane amount of ground already, and it became quite clear to me that traversing through the vast landscapes in this environment was going to be a blast. Rico glides across the geography with ease, and I was looking forward to reaching my objective (flagged by a green marker in the screen, which was fortunately small enough that didn’t distract me, but contrasted enough with the environment that I could easily find it when I looked for it).

We start going up and down valleys, following some pipes, and you can avoid some baddies by taking the high route and staying out of their way. I wanted to see if the game was going to give me some combat tutorial, so I decided instead to go BOOM on them, which gave me the first chance to fire around.

My main impressions at this point were: (1) aiming and shooting with the Xbox controller is way harder than what I used to in Deus Ex playing with mouse and keyboard, (2) auto-aim and/or aim correction will be a must for me (I don’t know if it was on by default or not, but I could see the crosshair floating towards the enemy and I was grateful for that), and (3) Rico seems to have a decent amount of health and it regenerates quickly enough that I didn’t have to worry about it too much. I don’t want my experience to be too stressful, so I’ll keep these settings and difficulty levels even if the game offers me the chance to ramp them up.

A few minutes of grappling, shooting and parachuting later, I’m at the literal top of the world (or at least what I have seen of it so far). I quickly went towards the objective, which was a control panel that I hacked while being showered by bullets. There was a short opportunity to drive a utility vehicle into a pile of exploding barrels and I was shot so much and still survived without an issue, and then quickly the tutorial mission ended and I was greeted with the title screen. In less than 30 minutes, I felt that I understood the basic game controls and travel mechanics, and felt very excited to continue playing. While I believe my aim suffered a lot from being on an Xbox controller, movement is the core of the game and it feels much easier to move around with a dual analog stick than with a mouse/keyboard combo and I’ll probably keep playing with the controller.

The reality is that, after the tutorial, there are still a few additional missions that are aimed mostly at teaching aspects of the game, namely, Supply Drops, territorial expansion, Grapple Lifter, Grapple Booster, and Retractor. You also learn how to manage troops across the map, but at this point, I feel that both the tutorial and the story are quite rushed and not necessarily coherent. Characters are introduced extremely quickly without any background, and then they are fundamental parts of the story and you’re supposed to care for them. Sorry, but I don’t. 

If the story keeps being a miss, the gameplay and the graphics remain a plus. Moving around Solis is a blast. Better if you start at the high ground and can glide across the landscape, but moving to high ground is not a big deal with the help of your grapple. I quickly learned to grapple the ground, gain some momentum and then lift off with the parachute, and this seems to be the main mode of transportation across the island.

The story tries to tease you about some kind of spontaneous revolution started by Rico, but if we’re being honest, it’s very flaky. It’s just too convenient and hard to believe. It doesn’t really matter so much since your main goal is to gain ground and kaboom things, but it would be a nice plus if you had the world fleshed out a bit more and believable characters instead of just throwing a lot of random story bits and hoping they stick (spoiler alert - they don’t stick).

That’s when you start to be introduced to more missions. Some of the earlier examples include escort when you jump on top of a moving truck and kaboom all the other vehicles that approach; prisoner liberation, where you go into a base, open some prison doors, protect prisoners, and make everything else go kaboom; and transport, where you drop a helicopter (?) from a container in front of you (??) and become a pilot for someone that I barely know who it is (but it doesn’t matter, as long as you go kaboom at some point).

It took me a while until I finally figured out the core gameplay loop - it’s all about territorial liberation. When you start the game, most of the map is dominated by your enemy, the Black Hand. You have to generate a type of resource named “Squads” to liberate more territory, and you do so by kabooming things and exploding Black Hand infrastructure more generally. The amount of Squads necessary to liberate an area depends on the neighboring areas, so there’s a strategic element to which areas you liberate, and in which order - so you don’t run out of squad resources.

Some areas also require region strike missions to be accomplished before you can move your squads in, and these missions usually involve visiting the area and causing chaos - for instance, messing with the Black Hand airport in Islas Intichayers, or stealing a warship in Recalada.

My biggest complaint is that it’s not entirely clear how this system is supposed to work when you first start playing. Sure, the game has a mini tutorial that explains the mechanic, but not the logic or strategy behind it, and since this is such an open-ended world that gives you so many degrees of freedom, it’s hard to even know where to start. I had to rely on a walkthrough after reading on Reddit that, starting in the “wrong” order could cause you to be locked outside regions without troops and with high costs to advance, whereas the “right” order would have you taking region after region for free, if not earning troops when you do so. It’s great that the game is open, but if that openness gets in your way of properly advancing through the game, that’s a failure.

133760676.review:
I recommend this game but just barely. It can be good fun especially if your a fan of the series but it does not live up to just cause 2 or 3. I have 100% completed this game and then uninstalled directly after. It is not a game i ever intend on playing again or replaying. I am a fan of the series but seeing reviews being mixed i held off and bought on sale and got all of the dlc's i recommend you do the same.

Pros- 
*Fun game mechanics.
*Large map
*Beautiful areas to explore.
*Lots of content
*numerous vehicles to play with.

Cons-
*Sometimes there is too much content. repetition is enough to make you drink with all the stunts and everything this game has you doing over and over.
*Why can i grapple parachute hoverboard fly launch missiles off my back but only carry 2 weapons at a time.In my opinion this is a great disservice and there should be a weapon wheel with more weapon unlocks being added to it and a primary focus on ammo like in Grand theft auto. (Wow i can't believe i said that either) but that system would work so well in this game.
*Cut scenes are horrendous. In most games they look better than the game. In this it feels like someone swapped my graphics card for the time being to something from the 90's then right back after it's over.
*Honestly the story is probably 6-8 hours of this game and the rest is collecting this or that and finding locations.
*The missions could be longer they don't take very much time at all to finish.
*the dlc's are ok but i didn't want more stuff to hunt down or a damned hoverboard i was forced to use.
*I really missed the mechanic like JC3 had where there were locations and you had to destroy things to clear the location. I feel as if that should have been present not solely but mixed in as well as having stunts. Some locations are stunts others are destruction.
*Grappling hook while parachuting is awful it seems there isn't as much reach as what you had in JC2 or JC3 which would often leave me stranded in free air in scenarios where i did not or could not use the glider suit.

I could probably go on forever but in summary i give it a 2/5. Its fun but after buying it i put it down immediately probably for the better part of 2 years. I finally made it my job to finish this game so it wasn't looking at me all the time and i had another 100% on my steam account. I say job because most of the time in this game was not fun but more like something i wanted to get out of the way. I hope this helps. It's an easy 100% it just takes time. i say play it but don't expect a whole lot.

133281361.review:
Before I even begin, this is my first Just Cause game. Rip me up and down for it, I've heard wonderful things about 2 and 3, but nothing good about 4. Literally the only reason I got 4 was tornado go brrr. Note I got every achievement and have a good chunk of hours into the game. Here's the gist of things:

GRAPHICS
- Its visually pleasing to look at for its release date, for a 2018 game its decent to look at and nothing looks or feels too bad.

COMBAT
- It's bare bones. You do one thing wrong in front of an enemy they will endlessly come at you until you either run away or die. It's not like GTA where they get harder as you gain stars but instead its based on the vehicle you're operating (e.g. they send helicopters if you're in one | they send tanks if you're in a ground vehicle)

STORY/QUESTS
- I can't make this up, apart from the side quests there are only 10 STORY QUESTS, 3 for each region and 1 for the final mission which was VERY very lackluster. The downloadable content side missions are mid as well. They tried to lengthen the game by locking quests based on the regions you have conquered.

OPEN WORLD STUFF
- There is an ungodly amount of "stunt" open world mini quests to do, I spent literally 14 hours in one day just to finish them (they take way longer than that), they make you do these stunts to unlock new weapons and vehicles. 

PHYSICS
- Mobility in this game is its strong point with the grappling system. Its entertaining to lift enemies and vehicles into the sky or launch cows using the booster perk. The physics can be janky at times, if you shoot a tank at a specific angle with another tank, it will launch into the sky. If you ram a car at a high enough speed sometimes they go flying. Controlling boats and planes are absolutely abysmal and aren't fun to control at all.

BUGS
- There aren't a lot of bugs in the game, but the times I did experience bugs they were always game breaking. Examples being getting stuck inside a freight boat and not being able to get out or blow it up, or after dying and the lighting starts to flash uncontrollably. 

There's probably a lot more that I could say about this game. Its not a bad game but its no that great of a game, once you finish the story it just kinda sucks after since there's nothing much to do. If you really like Just Cause I'd wait for an 80% off sale or just buy it off of G2A or something, I dont recommend buying this game at full price and I will say I didn't enjoy this game to the fullest

132811311.review:
Crazy physics chaos simulator. Improves on 3 in many ways. 
Best thing compared to 3 in my opinion is that this always has a war going on in the background and you are very much fighting in it as well. With front lines that have some pretty fierce fighting going on. 
Its not about the story even though I think its not too bad but you probably wont get too attached to many characters and will forget who some are by the time you get back to them depending on how your playing the game. But when you forgive its shortcomings what you have here is a really fun chaos first person shooter that could be best described as bionic commando on steroids. The overall variety of units rolling around on both sides seems better as well. Fighter jets will target you and you will run into groups of tanks and helicopters and of course troops etc all mixing and getting crazy in the field. Its a lot of fun to just watch the crazy @#$% that happens sometimes as it can get comical in a what the hell just happened way. I think this game actually deserves a better rap because it is just a heck of a lot of fun.

131833541.review:
- Some of the most beautiful explosions tied around some of the most fun sandbox environments filled with so many ways to perform some of the coolest stunts from your favorite action movies that by the time you think you've exhausted all of them, a new idea pops into your head and it's back into the thunderstorm/sandstorm/tornado once more.

- Very well optimized (running on a GTX 1050 2GB mind you, on an I5-8300h, a real potato machine..... and it not only manages to stay alive during a session, but keeps a relatively stable framerate as well, 40-60 range), if not the most graphically impressive game, certainly not as pretty as Just Cause 3 but also more reliably smooth and visually diverse.

- A story that once again doesn't take itself too seriously, features the Latino James Bond and Ethan Hunt lovechild performing badass shit as usual and actually manages to give Rico a somewhat decent and compelling backstory with action movie tropes of family, friendship and rebellion against a tyrannical government that once again works as well as it did in prior entries. The characters are not as memorable or funny as the cast of JC 3 in my opinion, no MOORIO :( but Rico and Sheldon's relationship I thought got a very compelling arc throughout this game, as these two have gone from student mentor, to surrogate son and father, to untrustworthy ally and compadre to finally brothers in arms fighting back against the very agency that made them the people they are today (this gets particularly well-fleshed out in the game's Danger Rising DLC, which was my favorite Expansion of the 3 available in the Complete and Gold editions of the game). So overall, the story fits the action, and the action fits the story, good.

131043784.review:
I tried to like this series, but it didn't click with me at all. The first game has a really outdated gameplay, it was so bad I quit. JC2 gets a 100% better gameplay, but it had a problem that persisted in the other entries: you MUST grind to unlock the main missions. 
I have no problem to grind when I love a game, but when it's just another generic third person shooter with very underwhelming plot, I just want to play the main missions and be done with it. This is no Final Fantasy, the grinding gets stale and boring fast but you're obligated to do it to unlock main missions. To make things worse for JC4, the gameplay became confusing and it was a downgrade from JC3 (JC3 is the best in the series, for better or worse). The graphics are horrible for an AAA game released on 2018. If I had played it on PS Plus or Gamepass I would never had bough it. Give me one Final Fantasy or let me play GTA5 for the fourth time, even though I spent lots of hours on JC2 and JC3, I don't think I'll finish those games..

Just started gaming not too long, got JC4 for free on Epic, first JC game ever, thought it was alright. 1-2 years later bought JC3, after 100% it still didn't get why JC4 got so much hate. Bought JC4 again this sale for dlcs and OMG the game is boring AF, not worth it even on sale.
They removed everything fun about JC, you get a downgraded version of the jetpack, the mech no longer has range weapon, idk if it's just me or the server is down because the leaderboard is empty, no more liberate but instead of you have to do side quests and challenges to unlock stuff, Ubisoft style which I now despite, the map and the progression system are so fkn confusing most of the time I have no idea of what to do to unlock the next quest, instead of liberating bases now you have to do stupid stuff like free prisoners and protect them until they reach the exit with the speed of 3 bullets per freedom, defend a stupid transmitter, get a vehicle and bring some trainees with you to shoot some random things, do some "stuns", do some tomb raider shenanigans, no more secret weapons but instead now you can destroy some big skulls that are scattered around the map, there are no sense of progression, nothing you do feels like it matter or change anything, the list goes on.

129685410.review:
[b]Just Cause 4[/b] is the sequel for Just Cause 3 which failed at so many spectacles and it's just a huge step down from previous installments, though there are some fun to be had even with its many flaws.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
- Performance was great
- Huge map with different biomes
- Capybaras, yes you read that right
- Causing chaos is just as fun as it always was
- Combat is great most of the time
- You can upgrade your tether abilities
- Some dialogues actually made me giggle
- Lots of challenges to do
- Huge variety of guns and vehicles
- Soundtrack is okay
- Lots of regions to liberate
- Steam trading cards, achievements

[b][u]Neutral:[/u][/b]
- You can unlock most guns, vehicles etc by completing challenges in quite weird ways.
- The tornado, sandstorm and the blizzard weather cores are interesting for the first time you see one, then it's just meh

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- Tons of bugs
- Square Enix servers are not responding at all so forget about competing with your friends
- Story is just not great, it has its moments but overall it's bad
- The progression is horrible
- The main villain is the most underwhelming one in the series, you see him at the beginning and at the end of the game and that's it, just laughable
- Most characters are not memorable at all.
- Visuals most of the time looks like hot garbage even on max settings
- Pre rendered cutscenes look awful
- Janky controls, you can die the most absurd ways thanks to it.
- Janky driving with most vehicles, the camera makes it worse
- The FOV is straight up horrendous and you cannot change it [i](There is a mod that lets you change it)[/i]
- Side activities are insanely boring I did not want to spend any more time with them to
- Horrible [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TheBeggarSoldier/recommended/868424/]Expansion Pass[/url]

[b]5.5/10[/b] This entry to the franchise is the most weakest and most underwhelming one. This might also be the downfall of the once beloved Just Cause franchise, though a sequel was teased at the end of the game.

I would give it a meh rating instead of a negative one, but no I wouldn't recommend buying it only if the game is on sale or if you are a diehard fan of the series.

129605560.review:
After playing for only 2 hours, I was already left feeling disappointed with what I had seen. The open-world setting and the ability to cause chaos and destruction were definitely cool, but the lack of meaningful progression and the poor performance of the game made it feel kind of repetitive and frustrating.

The story and characters in Just Cause 4 weren't particularly engaging either, which made it hard to become fully invested in the game. Without a compelling story or well-developed characters, the gameplay can feel shallow and unfulfilling, even with the ability to cause chaos.

It's worth noting that open-world games can often take a significant amount of time to complete, and it's possible that I may have missed out on some of the more interesting aspects of the game if I only played for 2 hours. However, based on my limited experience with the game, it seems likely that the issues I experienced may have persisted throughout the game. Overall, I was left feeling disappointed and would not recommend it to others.

129039898.review:
I just finished JC4 and played it for 66 hours. If I had written a review after an hour or two I would have slammed it. Although I had read negative reviews so my expectations were low, my initial impression was total disappointment. Having enjoyed JC, JC2 and even JC3 (which I felt was a bit of a let-down compared to JC2) this one seemed all wrong. I think it was mostly because of the new method of taking ownership of territory using the chaos meter and of course the weird menu. But it also felt that the game was forcing me into it too fast and I was just fighting enemy forces instead of being in control of a new adventured.

Having paid over £10 for everything (which is a lot for someone who normally only buys games at 80% discount in the Steam sales) I had to persevere with the game so I took my Rico away from the main action and focused on the game mechanics and menu so that I could adapt to it, and then played some of the dlc "side missions" and challenges at my own pace. That made me feel back in control so that I could then progress the main missions. Gradually the game felt a whole lot better and I started to enjoy it.

As others have noted, some of the graphics aren't great and the mechanics aren't as good as they should be - grappling hook accuracy varies and some of the vehicles are almost undriveable. The game design is reasonable, although there is a bit too much repetition where it could have been avoided, and some of the challenges are badly thought out and a bit pointless. The extra features of the grappling hook seemed clever but I couldn't get into them. They felt over-complicated and not entirely intuitive. Often I had to edit the mode in order to get it to do what I wanted. That's probably why the designers had created profiles but I just wasn't that interested. I enjoyed the story and the addition of the 3 dlcs lengthened gameplay to more than 60 hours.

I think I disagree with many reviewers: In my opinion JC4 is in some ways better than JC3. However I think that JC and JC2 were more fun.

128982290.review:
It's not bad, but its not great either. Coming off JC3 I was very disappointed with many of the changes they made here.

The BAD

1. No handheld explosives like in JC3 - instead you have to either engage with the new grapple systems or use the new alt fire modes found on most guns to get sort of real damage output against objects and vehicles.

2. the new grapple mechanics - imo the balloons are a gimmick which are good for a bit of messing around but not very helpful for actually clearing bases and the novelty wears off quckly. I miss the much stronger grapple from JC3 which could easily pull helicopters out of the sky. The default grapple here feels much weaker even when toggling it to its strongest pull.

3. enemies - once your alert meter goes up it can feel like a chore to get enemies off your back as they seem to pursue you for far longer and further than in JC3. they also seem to spawn more quickly as I rarely felt like I had actually cleared an area because new enemies would always pop up

4. activities - the flashy 5 star/gear system and reward screen in JC3 made every activity feel meaningful. In JC4 side activies like wingsuit courses feel hollow and not worth doing as there arent any great rewards and theres not even a screen popping up to say you did it in most cases.

5. bases - the goal is no longer about destroying red objects - you know, the straightforward objective of each base in JC3 that encouraged using the sandbox to wreak havoc? Red objects actually respawn now and the only point to destroying any of it is getting points towards the conquest mechanic which is token at best. This is already a huge disappointment but then each base now has an actual objective to do. This sounds cool on paper but the missions get recycled a lot and many of them now involve escorting NPCs or protecting an object - which I shouldn't have to explain is a very poor choice for a series about high mobility and explosions

6. vehicles - vehicles have ammo now which seems unnessecary. Some vehicles have enough ammo you'll never run out but others like the bomber jet seem to have enough for 1 or 2 runs before you may as well ditch the vehicle. Ground vehicles like tanks seem to be made out of paper now while air vehicles seem to be able to take more hits than in JC3 which is strange.

7. graphics - my PC is not very high spec anymore so take this with a grain of salt but I swear the graphics are worse here than in 3.

The GOOD

1. story - its hardly a work of art but the story is fine for the type of game this is. Its mostly held together by a few entertaining characters though Rico himself seems rather low energy for most of the game

2. story missions -credit where its due there are some cool moments here - the region finales involving the weather mechanics are the highlight with tornadoes, thunderstorms and sandstorms. Id even go so far as to say that the best missions here are a way bigger spectacle than any one mission in JC3.

3. map - personally I like Medici more but theres decent variety here with jungle, desert, and grassland regions

At the end of the day its a JC game and there is definitely some fun to be had here, especially if this is your first time with the series. For me though I felt that JC4 made unnecessary changes to the formula that took away what I liked so much about JC3, and it ends up being a very hollow experience where I finished the game and immediately went back to JC3 instead.

128455676.review:
Finished JC3 up to 100%, loved it for the crazy stunts and overall mayhem you can cause with your tethers, bavarium wingsuit and various explosives. I bought JC4 expecting a decent sequel and after a couple of hours posted this critic so... Let's see what I got.

[h1]Loyal to its older brother : 8/10[/h1]
JC3 was all about having fun with the unrealistic physics, grappling around and using your wingsuit to jump unsuspecting ennemies and destroy their whole base without them being able to do anything against you. And JC4 does it quite well. It even jump starts and bypasses the lengthy upgrading system in JC3 by giving you, right at the start of the game, 10 tethers (more than the 6 tethers limit in JC3) and in a couple of missions (less than 30 minutes of gameplay) provides you with the boosters and the air lifter. Overall, the reason I "only" gave it an 8/10 is because they unnecessarily changed the way you free the areas of the map. In JC3 you have to find several spots in each area, destroy all chaos objects and you were done. Here there is a bit less destruction involved and it is more like about completing certain missions, then ordering your "troops" to move in another area in which you will repeat the process. I think the idea was to make it feel like Rico needs the island's people to win but it sounds silly considering that the NPCs are just as useless as they were in JC3. Seriously, I just did a mission for which I need to take two NPCs with me drive in a car for several kilometers to destroy 4 boxes. It took me almost 10 minutes to get it done whereas doing it by myself with the wingsuit would have taken me less than 2 minutes. Basically you are still a one man army and you could install a mod that removes every member of the resistance and you wouldn't feel any difference. I think JC5, if it is made one day, should take this one man army seriously : the cutscenes should be about NPCs telling Rico that he needs their help to kill the evil dictator and Rico answering "Hey, I just destroyed 5 ennemy bases by myself without a scratch, don't worry about me, just stand back and enjoy the show".
Anyway, overall it is enjoyable, fun to play and the feeling is similar to what you had in JC3 between the gunfights, the wingsuit/parachute combo, the tethers and the handling of the fun and unrealistic physics.

[h1]Chaos mechanics : 4/10[/h1]
In JC3, the usual way you free an area was : head to this area, discover the N settlements in it (small bases, big bases, outposts...), destroy every chaos object in these settlements and the area becomes yours and the rebels now occupy these settlements.
In JC4, they removed this idea that you had to cause mayhem and destruction. Basically you do the 2 or 3 missions you can find in an area, during which you will have to kill black hand's soldiers, which generates chaos which grants you "rebel squads". These squads are "stored" somewhere in your... Inventory ? Whatever, basically you accumulate squads and once you have enough (between 2 and 4 for most areas) you click on the map to say "hey, rebels, go free this area", at which point the rebels establish a frontline where the constantly fight the black hand on the borders of this area. Then you do the missions in this area, accumulate a few more squads and proceeed to the next area. I do not like this idea, not only is it a fake way of pushing the idea that "Rico is just a man, he can't take the black hand by himself, he need help from the rebels who can't even kill a single foot-soldier in 5vs1 in less than 1 minute" even though you can move around freely on the whole map and utterly destroy any black hand squad you encounter. I really feel like the devs saw a few videos on youtube of players utterly destroying some black hand military bases and decided that "oh no, we can't have that, we need the player to work hand in hand with the rebels, it's much more realistic than a single man freeing a country !". I'm not exactly sure what was the motivation here, but it is a big failure, the amount of chaos you have to generate in "roaming" when you just mess with the black hand is absurd, i litterally spent 15 minutes destroying almost 50 helicopters and 50 armed cars and killing several soldiers, it only granted me 1/10th of a squad.

[h1]Graphics : 5/10[/h1]
Similar to JC3, graphics are not particularly great, personnaly I don't care about this in video games so it doesn't bother me. Just a quick note about the level design : the starting area (wachikuni, terra del qhapaq, hamparas...) looks a lot like what you can find in some parts of Ghost recon : Wildlands. 

[h1]Keyboard controls : 3/10[/h1]
Dear video games developers, for the last fucking time, no, no and no, I do not want, under any circumstances, to spend 15 minutes in the controls menu setting up my keys for walking, then for piloting a plane, then for piloting a helicopter, then for driving a car, then for FOR FUCK'S SAKE WHO IN THIS WORLD USES DIFFERENT MOVEMENT KEYS BETWEEN THEIR CHARACTER MOVEMENTS AND THE VEHICLE MOVEMENTS ??? I don't get it. I also do not want to have to go through the 13 different menus to see what action is the 'X' key bound to if I want to use it for something. Binding keys should not be that hard : you double click on an action, you press the key you want to attribute to this action, and if it is already bound the game either highlights the conflict or switches both keys. Then you display every action in the same menu with categories, you do not split it between 13 submenus.
While we are talking about the menus, if you have the sound and the sensitivity set as values between 0 and 100 (it goes even beyond 100 for the sensitivity, I don't understand how scales work in your minds but whatever), you either use a slider or provide us with an input to quickly change it, I don't want to hold my right arrow for 30 seconds to reach the value I want. 
Driving feels as weird as some of the games with the weird driving system I have ever seen like Ghost Recon: Wildlands and Watch Dogs 1. No intertia, your car's tires are basically made of oil, but frankly aside from missions that require me to use a car I stick to the good old wingsuit so it's not that much of a bother. 

[h1]Story : 0/10[/h1]
If you played JC3 for its story, you're weird. The story of JC3 was worthy of a very low-budget serie Z movie, and the same can be said for JC4. You start by attacking a base by yourself, you handle everything they throw at you, and suddenly cut-scene and you lose and get shot down. Had the game left the controls to you, the final boss would have been dealt with in less than 10 minutes. 
I rated it 0/10 but lets be frank, it is like rating minecraft's graphics 0/10 : the mark is deserved, but just like you're not supposed to care about minecraft's graphics, you're not supposed to care about Just Cause's story. It's a silly story that doesn't make the slightest sense, and it doesn't matter at all.

[h1]Overall : 1/10[/h1]
Had I posted this evaluation yesterday, the overall note would have been 7/10 and my explanation for it : 
[code]I wouldn't say it is a must play, but it is a decent sequel to JC3. About as fun as its older brother, JC4 is rather enjoyable but unless you are a hardcore fan of the series, I would advise to wait for some discount, I wouldn't considering spending more than 15-20€ for it.[/code]

And started a new game. And erased my current save. Apparently it wasn't frozen. 128453920.review:
Kinda meandering, no real drive to do anything, pretty much the same objectives copy pasted, and I hated most of the controls. Aiming with anything but guns had a sort of 'lag', as though the crosshair was constantly a bit behind / trying to move ahead. The guns had some as well, but they were bearable.

Wingsuit / Grapple just wasn't fun to use together, at least until it handed me a jetpack one randomly. That was okay, but still way too slow to turn / lift up. Also using space as a 'instant jump out of vehicle' caused the loss of a few nice helicopters. 128046051.review:
Just Cause 4 is an open-world third-person shooter with a definite focus on explosions, unrealistic but fun physics, and horribly over-the-top but very enjoyable destruction. This also unfortunately means that the story is again stupid, full of woefully flat, uninteresting characters and their lifeless motivations.
You lead the traditional revolution in the role of the protagonist Rico Rodriguez across the fictitious island of Solis. The world is a joy to look at. The landscape is beautiful, rugged, the views diverse and breathtaking. You will look at different types of forests, at snow-capped mountain tops and fly through the hot air swirling over the stony desert. The hills, plains, meadows and fields do not look machine-made, artificial, so there is no problem at all in believing them.

The game was able to revive slightly with three DLCs, without which I do not recommend buying JC4.
The first is called Dare Devils and deals with racing. Of course, racing with absolutely no rules, during which you will use your driving and shooting skills in approximately the same measure.
The second DLC called Demons (locally Los Demonios) is the most appealing in my opinion. The whole landscape will be possessed by hellish forces and Rico will have to deal with a supernatural enemy.
The latest expansion, Agency Strikes Back, will bring with it the elite soldiers of Rico's former employer - highly trained, perfectly armed and completely motivated. Their motivation: Rico's liquidation.

You will destroy, scatter, ravage, smash, demolish, blast, shoot, run over, detonate, demolish, launch, shoot and finally liquidate some more.. JC4 offers crazy action response. [b] 30% [/b]

127467730.review:
This game is a buggy mess. 

- Denuvo.
- The most counterintuitive keyboard commands you could fathom. Why is 1 map and not M? I'm 20 hrs in and I still don't know which gun is which number to switch between just TWO weapons. The game doesn't tell you in your HUD and the only other short cut is to HOLD DOWN R to switch. Why is exit backspace and not esc? Why are some helicopters controlled by the direction you look in, but others you have to navigate pitch and yaw like a flight simulator? 
- Waypoint pathing is a drunk seagull. At one point, one of the missions had you deliver a vehicle under a bridge and the game was so confused about its own waypoint that it basically drew circles around the area using its pathing with crayons, swooping in, shitting all over everything, and then leaving you to navigate on your own.
- The side missions are basically all vehicle based, but vehicle navigation is decidedly not a strong point. The heat system is somehow much worse in JC4 and after reading several forum posts I still can't figure out when the game decides you drop heat. 
- Not ultrawide compatible. Somehow, the only UI that's broken is when you request travel, upon which your options are hidden unless you change your graphics settings to windowed.
- They ran out of time to do cutscenes so they inserted storyboards which literally look like filler storyboards you'd put in a game when you ran out of time to do cutscenes.

I've played every single JC4, and every single Far Cry and not only do you not get the story and exploration of FC but JC4 has managed to fix a bunch of things that are not broken. I'm glad I didn't pay for this game.

127108155.review:
Just Cause 4 is an action-adventure video game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Square Enix. The game was released in December 2018 and is available on multiple platforms including PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and PC.

The game's storyline revolves around the main character, Rico Rodriguez, who is a skilled operative working for an agency called The Agency. In the game, Rico is tasked with stopping the evil Black Hand organization from taking over the fictional South American country of Solis.

The gameplay in Just Cause 4 is very similar to its predecessor, with the main focus being on exploration and destruction. The game features an open-world environment that is massive in scale, giving players plenty of space to explore and cause chaos. The game also introduces new tools for the player to use, such as the grapple hook that can be used for traversal and as a weapon.

One of the highlights of Just Cause 4 is the game's visuals, which are stunning. The game features beautiful environments, realistic lighting, and impressive weather effects. The game's sound design is also noteworthy, with a great soundtrack that fits the game's overall tone and action-packed gameplay.

However, despite the impressive visuals and sound, the game suffers from a number of technical issues that can detract from the overall experience. Some players have reported issues with performance and stability, and the game's AI can be quite buggy at times.

Another issue with the game is its repetitive missions and lack of variety. While the game's open-world environment is impressive, many of the missions feel similar, and there is a lack of variety in the game's enemies and objectives.

Overall, Just Cause 4 is a fun and action-packed game that is worth playing for fans of the series. The game's open-world environment and impressive visuals are definitely highlights, but the technical issues and lack of variety in missions can detract from the overall experience.

125122510.review:
El 3 fue una experiencia divertidísima. Llegabas, mirabas y destruías a placer, las fuerzas de seguridad suponían un reto aceptable. 
En esta nueva entrega, los personajes secundarios tienen la mitad de la mitad, de la mitad del carisma que tenían los del 3, que ya de por sí era poca. Los diálogos se sienten muy genéricos, los personajes se sienten hechos de cartón. A veces el juego se ve bonito, pero la inteligencia artificial de las personas es lamentable. Los personajes se atascan con los objetos y los vehículos forman colas infinitas si te paras en frente de un vehículo en la carretera.

Sin duda una cosa que me molestó bastante, algo que me estaba exasperando era el sistema de alerta del juego, en el que, si atacabas un vehículo de los Mano Negra, o cualquier mínima falta frente a ellos, te dabas la vuelta y tenías un helicóptero disparándote misiles, un convoy de autos buscándote por toda la ruta y hasta un bombardero jodiendo con precisión milimétrica. Era imposible tener un poco de diversión sin que tuvieras a todo el ejército detrás de ti. Quizás sea mi impresión, pero eso me pareció bastante desbalanceado. 

De por sí esta franquicia no se ha caracterizado por tener una historia muy sólida, ni por tomarse muy en serio a sí misma, incluso ni siquiera le hace falta una historia, porque lo que gusta es tener una excusa para destruir todo y a todos a tu paso, pero aquí hay menos destrucción, los pueblos/ciudades ahora ya no tienen ningún elemento interactivo, ninguna razón para visitarlos, aparte de ver a los ciudadanos tropezarse con una silla una y otra vez. 

Pero lo que realmente me hizo dejar el juego fue la imposibilidad de poner el juego en pantalla completa, no hay configuración in-game que me permita jugar en pantalla completa. El juego me apaga el monitor cada vez que se inicia porque la pantalla completa no funciona. Y para ponerme a hacer malabares con archivos de texto, prefiero ponerme a jugar cualquier otra cosa que funcione.

124818480.review:
A game I could only really describe as 'only exists because it's a cash-cow sequel.'  It's also a bug-riddled bad-physics hell which deserves refunding.

If this had been released as Just Cause 1, it would've been slammed so hard into the ground by reviews that the only thing 'hot' about it would be its average temperature upon reaching the Earth's mantle.  Just about everything in this iteration is exactly that: an iteration, and sadly not very many are good ones.  The wingsuit controls are SO bad.  The game is full of sloppy ideas that sound way cooler than they perform, physics that just feels more off than the last 3 games, controls and AI logic that are hard to wrap your head around, it's honestly a shame this game has as many cool concepts as it does, because that's probably the only other reason it moved as many numbers as it did, apart from die-hard fanboys desperately clinging to a sinking ship.

It's also impossible to escape the black hand forces once they start sending air units after you, as they just keep spawning helicopters and drones right behind you indefinitely, or they'll send a jet which is impossible to shoot down without homing missiles.  It's actually easier and more playable to just die and restart at that point.

[b]More Playtime Edit[/b]

God, it's so bad.  Omniscient AI.  DLC equipment that doesn't interact with other DLC equipment.  Instant death because one random sniper shot you in the face.  Every vehicle but the mech is made of Papier-mâché and tacky glue, causing you to die if you so much as think about brushing against any terrain for any reason.  Extremely un-fun and spammy DLC enemies.  An entire car-driving DLC in a game where making a left turn over 20 mph is a herculean task.  They even took out all the fun of the jetpack from the 3rd game and replaced it with a total nothing 'upgrade' system that just makes it useless faster.  This game is such wasted potential that it makes me angry.

Don't bother picking this one up.  Just go back and play 3, or even 2.

124350195.review:
A big downgrade from Just Cause 3

I haven't played the Just Cause series from the first one and was introduced with the 3rd one. This game is nothing like the 3rd one. I feel like nothing is smooth in this game especially combat and changing grapple options.

Many times I found my guy running on top of a car and refusing to just run off the edge to get onto the ground. He wouldn't just hop down. I had to JUMP high up and over to be able to get down. I tested this many times and found it to happen repeatedly on surfaces that weren't very high up. I could understand doing it on tall buildings to prevent accidental deaths / running off (you have a parachute anyways) but being barely above the ground was a tedious chore. I'd have to grapple, leap, move and then reposition to continue to try to run / grapple onto objectives at times which was a nuisance.

The weapon layout / swapping was annoying too. I was hoping for a radial menu or some sort of quick selection but the best I could find was scrolling the mouse wheel. You can only have 2 weapons that I've found so far. Half of the weapons I've found aren't even worthwhile to use or have. I feel like the arsenal they put into this game is very poor and poorly balanced as well.

The grappling system requires you to go to the map, go into the layout system and changing it all over manually just to be able to hot swap to different ones instead of just giving you a radial menu to quick equip grapple effects. I think a radial would've been more intuitive especially for people using the controller (I never found one for controller) to use. So you could swap between regular grapple, to balloons to other effects quickly and without constantly having to go into menu in game to change it if you needed something different mid fight.

I feel like the flow of combat due to these issues was tedious and obnoxious. The developers didn't handle it very well and it is very poor to say the least. The overall way combat is handled is awful based upon my experiences in Just Cause 3. I'd recommend Just Cause 3 over 4 by a long shot.

Another thing I noticed is the graphics and character design. The way they designed certain character appearances seemed off and horrendous compared to Just Cause 3. In 3 they appeared smoother and more well defined. I'm playing this on higher settings with a modern GPU and they just don't seem well done at all. Even other friends of mine commented on how they preferred Just Cause 3 over 4 for this fact alone.

All in all this is not a game I enjoy or could get into very well due to the many issues that I have found. I would highly recommend Just Cause 3 over this one. This one leaves much to be desired in my opinion. I'm just glad this came in a HB pack so I didn't pay full price for it. I wouldn't even recommend this on sale. That's my personal opinion. Get Just Cause 3 instead. I believe you'll like it much better.

Overall rating for this game for me is a 3.5 out of 10. I wouldn't recommend it not even on sale. There are better options for "open world" action game play. This is one of the worst I've ever experienced.

124107786.review:
Franchise core elements were all gone other than the wing suit, parachute, and grapple. New element implemented as gracefully as attaching someone's broken legs to two separate dogs and training them to help a person walk.

Key binds are broken. I can not exit vehicles despite tapping or holding the buttons down if I swap keys around. This is a deal breaker. Especially since they never made plane or jets easier to fly on keyboard and mouse. You are strictly limited to pitch, yaw, and roll keys. Did I mention yawing is z and c rather than q and e? You can't change because the exit vehicle key will not work unless it's e. 

Game forces you to play story for progression and don't explain what you can do in the open word when they hand you the ability to free roam. 

AI path finding is completely degraded to it's basic function. It will not check if it can fly from point A to point B without accidentally committing a terrorist act.

The game changed too much from Just Cause 3 to Just Cause 4 without properly adjusting us to the game play. They removed the heat system's escalations and made it uniform, so difficulty no longer scales when you have the misfortune of requiring to bail out of your vehicle and get in trouble for it. It only gets worse when you realize enemies spawn around you Cyberpunk style. I wish I was joking. They did this to artificially make the game challenging in the least fair way possible. Minor touches to game immersion such as the explosive chisel have been removed. Everyone just leaves their doors and tank hatches unlocked because it would be unfair to the one man army with a grappling hook.

I found a runway with a plane and a bunch of explosive barrels on the runway. I got tipped over when trying to fly the plane out of the shack and spun backwards hitting obstacles. 

Conclusion: I wish I could refund this legal scam of a game. I'd get intimate with my ex a second time to make this game not be an absolute disgrace to the Just Cause franchise.

Take everything that makes Just Cause fun and stop it in a game.

In conclusion, just play JC2 or JC3.

123505294.review:
I honestly don't get the hate for this game - both from users AND critics for once.

Personally, I think that JC4, for me at least, has been as entertaining as JC2 for instance. I just couldn't get into JC3's unlock structure. It was too repetitive and boring for my taste. JC4 on the other hand has you liberating key regions (or all of them if you want to), having your guys take over control, but liberating a region means simply finishing ONE unique mission. There are a few repetitions, like escorting prisoners or driving cars with bombs attached into a lake, but I think most missions were unique and the other ones only repeated like once or twice, which is mostly fine. Quite a few of those missions also include a bit of story. Other than that you only need "troops" to take over the actual region. You get troops by causing "Chaos", but unlike in JC3, where you had to destroy EVERY GOD DAMN thing in a base (and do that like 100 times over to unlock the next mission), here you can simply destroy as you see fit. And most of that is done while on a mission anyway, just happens. By the end I GOT troops for liberating regions, instead of spending them anyway, since I was able to surround them, adding a small bit of "strategy" into the mix. I honestly think that combining a game like Just Cause with an RTS wouldn't be the worst idea out there. You set up the Chaos to make your troops push forward, but then you can directly control them or give orders to them ... maybe.

I'll mainly keep comparing this to JC3, so here goes:

Rico is finally back to his older self. He speaks with a Spanish accent again, instead of being a cheap Etzio Auditore knock-off, which was honestly were unsettling. He's gruffer, more restrained, less of a goof ball, more or less your typical 90s action hero. I liked that.

Same goes for the companions. None of them are even slightly irritating, compared to the insufferable Mario or the very cringe-worthy scientist lady in the former game ... even Sheldon acts like a person now, instead of the epitome of Texas cowboyism... he's turned into a somewhat likeable character.

The story is honestly fine for such a game. It's not ground-breaking, it doesn't need to be. My only real complaint is that the villains feel extremely flat. Apart from the very beginning and the very end they don't even appear. At least when going up against the various "cores" they could have included the general and fleshed out her story more, since she's related to your right hand woman ... there is room for improvement here. 

Mission design is alright as well, I liked it more than in JC3, since I felt like actually working towards a bigger goal. The side missions are alright. There's a scientist guy you can help uncover secrets of the past, which is a neat break from the regular gameplay, you're also helping a young commander train his troops on various missions (those are the weakest of the bunch to be honest, since they're mostly just regular gameplay) and help make a movie, which mostly involves racing from A to B, which is, despite the sometimes wonky driving physics, quite entertaining.

Side activities however are desastrously mundane ... you can either fly through a set of 3 hoops with your wingsuit, destroy blimps, or drive through checkpoints with specific vehicles found in the surrounding area. Very boring to be honest, but you need to do a few of those to unlock the actual side missions. You need points to do so ... and to upgrade your grappling hook.

Speaking of which: The grappler now comes in 3 different configurations: pull, float, boost. Each of these can be adjusted and equipped with various unlockables. None of them are even remotely necessary to complete the game, but it's nice having them ... and people love a good sandbox.

The island itself is beautiful, actually beautiful, it feels a lot more vibrant than the samey islands in JC3. You have djungles, grassy plains, tundra, deserts and snow-capped peaks, as well as the different weather phenomena, lightning, tornado, sandstorm, blizzard, which can be activated or deactivated, once you finish the respective mission. This was also a big USP of the game, but sadly, these disasters aren't as spectacular as they made them out. And the music overall is really fitting.

Gameplay feels more fluid as well, shooting and grappling especially. Gliding, wingsuiting and even hoverboarding all feel okay, and can be nicely combined with grappling. The flying controls are still shit though. Especially the camera, no matter which mode you choose, is atrocious when driving or flying. Helicopters are still a mess to use. Not sure if they'll ever have satisfying controls. That being said: Ain't much better in GTA5 (apart from the camera that is). It just snaps back too quickly and too soon when in fixed mode, but in free mode you're constantly adjusting it on the other hand.

I also don't get why people hate the map so much. I admit it might be a little confusing at the start, but you quickly get the hang of it and then it's quite alright. Fast travel is also much easier and comfortable in this game, as is having multiple different weapons or vehicles delivered right to your doorstep. These are unlocked through either just playing the missions or completing side activities. No longer do you have to find vehicles and drive them to a fucking Mario garage.

What else? The DLC sucks... here is where JC3 was a lot more interesting. Demonios can suck my ass, the agency one as well. Both offer minimal story, while re-introducing the hated JC3  repeat repeat repeat gameplay loop, as well as irritating flying enemies en masse! The demolition derby DLC is alright-ish if you just want something different for a change.

All in all my personal opinion is that JC4 is the best game in the series, despite the pre-rendered 30 FPS cutscenes, but for some reason most prefer JC3. I don't need to understand that, but maybe you're like me ... if you loved JC3, then this might not be to your liking though.

123475313.review:
The master of mayhem returns in [b][i]Just Cause 4[/i][/b], armed with his classic parachute, grappling hook and wingsuit combo, promising to wreak havoc on the oppressive forces of the fictional South American island of Solis. 

This time around Rodriguez has even more weaponry at his disposal to deal out the damage across the land. This arsenal includes everything from lightning guns to giant controllable tornadoes.

On the downside it's graphically lacking in places, a little short in terms of storyline, can get quite repetitive, and we're not convinced there's not enough newness to make this game quite great.

But if you're willing to spend time messing about with all the new grappling hook designs and unlocks, blasting enemies with a multitude of weapons and exploring your surroundings, then there's lots of fun and frolics to be had.

With [b][i]Just Cause 4[/i][/b] the developers set out to take all the features and gameplay that fans loved from the previous games and make a bigger and better experience. As such, fans will discover an immediate familiarity with how the game works and plays. This is both a good and bad thing.

[b][i]Just Cause 4[/i][/b] is the master of mindless destruction.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Plenty of daft fun to be had
- Easy checkpoint/save system
- Hilarious physics-based shenanigans
- Masses of weapons and vehicles to play with

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Graphics look a little dated and underwhelming
- You need to work for the fun
- Missions are highly repetitive

[h1]8/10[/h1]
DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | [b][u]GREAT[/u][/b] | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

I recommend this game, with a few somewhat damning caveats. 

As a preface, I beat the entire game and captured every region in a little less than 20 hours. This also includes completing the DLC mini-campaigns - which are genuinely awful in every way and I absolutely do not recommend. 

But, looking at the main game, its certainly fun. It is not, in my opinion better in any way than Just Cause 3. Just Cause is a good series, but it feels a little sad to have gone from an excellent 3rd game to a version that feels either scaled back or more fiddly than the sheer symphony of destruction the 3rd game was.

I recommend this game IF you have played and beaten Just Cause 3 and if you want a little more of Just Cause (and slightly more control over your grapples) than its worth getting this game.

123215246.review:
OK, I was a bit skeptical before playing Just Cause 4 because there’s a lot of negativity around it. And I can see that, in a lot of ways this game is worse that previous titles, and has issues. However, for me it’s not much worse, especially after playing the latest, complete version of the game and not playing this immediately after the previous titles. Actually, I really enjoyed this game overall and had a lot of fun with it, so this doesn’t deserve a negative review from me, or even a mixed one. You may be disappointed, yes, but overall, this is a good package.
Just Cause 4 for me felt like a mixture of Just Cause 2 and 3. It has the main gameplay elements from 3, but the map and completion length are more similar to 2. Gameplay is familiar if you played Just Cause 3. You have a grappling hook, parachute, and wingsuit that you can combo to travel around and help you in combat. The biggest improvement are the grappling hook mods, with tons of customization for different results. If you are bored, just try different combinations, and create your own fun, since this game gives you a lot of tools for that. Also, lots of guns with fun alternate fire effects, like firing an AI drone. My main issue with the gameplay is the driving, it feels clunky and a downgrade. Which is sad because the series for the first time has actual radio stations. And they’re pretty cool to boot!
The huge map is more similar to the Just Cause 2 one. In 3, it was beautiful, but had poor variety. Here, you have snow mountains, jungle, grasslands and desert. However, looking at the map, the placement of these zones feels a bit lazy and unnatural. It was much better in 2. Also, the desert is mostly big red formations, and the snow mountains lack settlements. So, while I prefer the map of 2, I think this one is overall better than the map in 3.
Just Cause 4 also has a lot of stuff to do, similar to 2, however I have an issue with it. Most of the stuff to do is just vehicle and wingsuit stunts, and they’re not even in the locations you discover. This way, you actually explore more of the map outside the locations, but since there’s not much else to track, like collectibles and stuff to destroy in the locations, when I complete a location, I feel I completed stunt events around a location, and not in the location itself. I have no problem with the stunts, but they could’ve added other stuff as well.
The story is basic, but that’s a standard for this series, I guess. This time, liberating regions has an army mechanic, that is confusing at first, but enjoyable when you figure it out. You actually push out your frontlines as you conquest more territory, and better yet, you actually see it. There’re battles happening everywhere, especially around the frontlines. I really enjoyed this mechanic, it helps the world feel alive, and reflects your progress. Plus, more chaos!
The graphics are alright, and the overall sound is ok. One of the main additions to the game is extreme weather events, like tornadoes. These events are really cool to experience, however they are very underused. The mostly appear in story missions, and rarely in the world. Adding them to more locations would help a lot.
Since I played the Complete Edition, there’s also a lot of extra content to enjoy, plus fixes and improvements since the release version. There’re 11 extra challenges, where you do miscellaneous stuff in the world, including more stunts. These stunts are harder in difficulty, but doable with some persistence and guidance. Extra weapons and vehicles are also available in the black market, including the awesome Mech Brawler, and the jetpack-wingsuit (why wasn’t this one included in the base game though).
3 major content DLCs are also available, of varying quality. Dare Devils of Destruction are race events mixed with destruction derbies, using modded cars with weapons attached. It’s cool, and all races are repeatable, although getting high scores can be annoying. Los Demonios adds a supernatural element, and it’s way harder than the base game. However, it’s not the good kind of hard, but cheap stuff killing you in seconds from nowhere. This DLC was frustrating to play, and definitely the worst part of the game, despite the cool concept.
Danger Rising is much better. It acts as an epilogue, and a teaser for the next game. It’s also harder to play, but in a good way. Enemies have more mobility and health, which can be annoying, but makes sense in the context of the story. At least you’re not cheaply dying anymore. It also has a real final boss, which the main game lacked. You also get a cool hoverboard, with courses available after beating the DLC. This DLC is the most polished, however there’s a bug preventing you to get 100% in it. At most, you can only get 92%, and that lowers the overall completion to 98%. Not a big deal since you can only see the percentage in a menu, but still annoying in a game about completion.
In the end, if you can get the Complete Edition on sale, it is an enjoyable experience, even if there are some elements that aren’t that good. I had a lot of fun with it, and laughed a lot, something only a few videogames manage to do. And a lot of that wasn’t scripted. While it is the 4th entry in the series, you can jump in here straight in, cause chaos and have fun.

This could be a very good game, except for the following.

What do I mean?

They have perfect evasive maneuvers and perfect aim.  Again, they, too, are magic and will only appear directly behind you.  There is no way to stop them, and no way to fight back.  This and the helicopters problem makes me think that the developers hate their customers in that they don't want them to fly around the game, DESPITE giving the player a fun jet pack and access to all flying vehicles.  "You can have these things, but you just can't use them for fun." -devs
 - Ground bases magically have enemy soldiers appear in infinite amounts and they, too, are perfectly accurate when shooting at you.
 - Many times something will just blow you out of the sky and you will have no idea where it came from and how it hit you, even though you may have been flying randomly.  It will still hit you and you will just fall from the sky unable to do anything because the recovery times takes about three days.


Despite the possibility of this game being a very fun very open-ended open world game full of exploration and multiple side quests to feel like you're making a difference in the game world, and making good progress, the developers have seen fit to completely ruin that with poor enemy programming and garbage enemy cheating.  It's so very frustrating that I cannot play this trash fire for more than a couple hours before I end up hating it because of the problems listed above.

122939263.review:
Just Cause 4 no es un mal juego, simplemente no aporta nada que no hayan hecho ya los anteriores. Una historia muy similar, una jugabilidad muy similar, unos enemigos muy similares, unas armas y vehículos que, como podéis imaginar, son también muy similares. Siendo tan continuista no puedo decir que sea malo, pero a mi (que me he jugado todos) me ha terminado cansando hacer tantas cosas tantas veces, sin verdaderas novedades. Y es que, en cantidad de contenido, el juego tiene un montón de cosas por hacer y explorar... pero son todas básicamente repeticiones de cinco o seis modelos de actividades repartidas por las localizaciones del mapa, con excepción de las misiones de trama. El resultado es un juego que se va desgastando a sí mismo debido a esa repetición. Y la aportación más novedosa, el sistema de personalización y mejora del gancho, acaba siendo meh, del mismo modo que los grandes desastres ecológicos (tornados, tormentas, etc.) acaban teniendo un impacto y una presencia muy puntuales.

Gráficamente el juego es discreto, lejos de ser un adalid y un portento, pero cumple. El sonido está bien, aunque el estilo de música es muy marcado y si no te gusta ese estilo pues te dedicas a apagar todas las radios como yo. Y el juego, como cualquier juego de mundo abierto, tiene bugs. No son terribles, pero sí que están presentes.

Por todo ello, no puedo recomendar Just Cause 4 salvo que quieras una dosis de violencia y acción random o no hayas jugado a los anteriores, momento en que todo esto puede saber nuevo. Un 4,5 para mi.

I can see why people might have been disappointed with JC4. It feels kinda short and there is less emphasis on blowing things up and more on just completing missions. Now the Squenix boss is chasing NFT's lol, but I digress.

My friend loaned me his pc to play this game. ITS FANTASTIC. It's a fantastic return to Just Cause 1's game design, Just Cause 2's variety, with Just Cause 3's technology. I can't fanboy enough about this game. The guns all have unique attachments to replace the Just Cause 3 grenades, the world is finally DESIGNED for the wingsuit. The story starts off a lot simpler so characters can have proper payoff (because there's only one writer). The Black Hand actually chase you down in tanks and helicopters so you can have NATURALLY OCCURRING ACTION SCENES.

Missions are back! And you don't need to talk to people to initiate them while you explore the world! You no longer have to scrounge bases for destructables, instead you're rewarded for finding them in other ways. It feels so much less like a chore!

Speaking of chores There's no longer any grinding to get your Just Cause 3 upgrades. You have most of them to start. All upgrades add on to your preexisting tool kit. Please Play Just Cause Four. Choose the desert instead of the Plains if you want variety early on. Squads are ONLY for story progression (the warfronts are icing on top). Step three Have a good time. :)

122527933.review:
TL;DR Absolute sh*tshow, avoid at all cost.

If you liked JC 1-3 and are playing with keyboard+mouse, do not buy (i don't use controller so can't give advice there). Or set a timer so you don't over that 2 hour limit and refund. I went over and can't do that. Stupid me... I really have liked the series and the free destruction in it, was hyped for the 4, and the result is a steaming pile of ****. I tried liking it but i can't. I [b]Just Can't 4[/b].. Remember when the devs took out the button-challenge for bombs and hijackings from JC2 away to streamline the gameplay for JC3? That was obviously the wrong direction for the devs. They want more button smashing, not less!

There is literally nothing better in this then in JC3, even graphics are similar to 3, it's just more jungle and more UI-crap on the screen that means nothing. So do yourself a favour and pick the Just Cause 3 (last good Just Cause-game) from a discount, put a couple mods in and enjoy much more then you could ever do in this ... game. 

Nothing works like the previous and well working games. Everything was changed and for the worse. In [b]Just Can't 4[/b] they doubled down on the controls so that many of the buttons need two functions, just so they could cram more things in. "Just Cause" and "buttons-galore" are not two things that belong in the same sentence. It's like the devs noticed there is thing called keyboard and they could cram more things into it then previously!

I can imagine the discussion:
Director: I want buttons for everything.
Coders: Everything..?
Director: EVERYTHING!!!
Coders: How about two functions for every button!?
Director: *heavy breathing*

The functions are scattered all around the keyboard with little logic. You need several hours to just learn and memorize the buttons and their functions. As a little example, the control options lists 4 different buttons for "next menu" and "previous menu". Where is that menu? It's button "1" where it previously was in "Tab". And the grab hook? They changed it from "mouse right" because heck, why not! It's only the most used thing in the game! "Right mouse" has now zoom aim. And that "mouse right" has to have two modes, press and hold, just so they could get more things in! And if you happen to have machine gun with a shield, it's a third button for one gun plus the mandatory reload button! And that previously working grab hook, the biggest and funniest thing in Just Cause-games..? There is now half a dozen buttons for it! You apparently can't tighten the tether yourself anymore, it does it automatically. But there is now two buttons for "quick-reel" because that was apparently a priority. Previously used "F" for throwing grenades was changed to the industry standard "Middle Mouse". Why? So they could cram more buttons for that "F"!!!

And all in all, everything that previously nice and neat, is now menus, CONSTANT mayhem (whether you wanted or not) and idiotic controls because .. i don't know. They like it confusing. It's not like nobody wanted to play a fun and casual game like Just Cause. More convenient to take button controls, mix them up in a bag and throw them to table and see how confusing they could make everything. I'm not going to spend hours to just get this game playable in menus and with mods, this game is dead to me. Make the next Just Cause like JC2 or JC3 and i'll consider buying. With big reservations.

122522058.review:
So, I went in with a decent brand loyalty, but unfortunately JC4 is just a bit... boring. I booted up the older game just to check if I had rose tinted goggles, but no. JC3 has much better polish. 4 wins out for raw sandbox capability, to be fair.

* JC3's map is much more usable and intuitive. It's easy to see what missions you have, and what the payoff will be. I still don't understand JC4's map, and I've written mapping software before...
* Some of the vehicle challenges are just chores. Having to find a specific vehicle... bleh. There was a surprising amount of "search an area for an object" missions, which I didn't find fun. Just put a waypoint on the object and let me get back to making poor/hilarious wingsuit choices.
* This might just be my mind playing tricks but I swear JC3's wingsuit controls much better. Responds faster? Not sure.
* Story is putting me to sleep. This isn't bad per se for a sandbox game, but in this instance it just leads to a dozen near-identical side (required) missions with the exact same objectives in almost the same environment. After a bit I got clearing them down to a (boring) science. Even the story missions relied heavily on the same formula, but at least the mission progression and environments were slightly different.

If this is your first Just Cause, just play 3! I loved getting close to 100% on 3 but I think I'm just gonna speedrun 4 and skip as much of the unlockables as possible.
