i think this is my first ever serious negative review. For context later; I play on an RTX 3080 & Intel i7-12700K, with 32GB of DDR4 RAM @ 3600 MHz.

I kept getting frequent freezes that lasted about half a second, about every 5 seconds. Genuinely unplayable, but I'm sure it was just a fluke. The cutscenes also look like they were rendered with the lowest settings possible at 30 fps, and on a 170hz monitor the cutscenes /hurt/. 

Oh, but that's not even the worst part; The default control layout. It's like someone saw the godawful controls of JC1 (or 2, I can't remember) and went ''Jamie, pull that control scheme up.'' They're TERRIBLE, and they're what I'd expect from a solo dev who's never touched a video game in his life. Who thought it was a good idea to make the default 'back' backspace? Or the selection button enter? 

I probably haven't given the game a fair shot, but I don't even want to. Go play Just Cause 3, it's far better.

122311833.review:
Its not the best just cause (for me personally Just Cause 2 is "the best") but it is Just Cause and it is fun. I've beat the game on another platform without dlc and am currently replaying on steam with dlc and still having fun.

Its got some of the best "chaos" caused by the ai of the series (if you stay anywhere for any amount of time an AI fight/attack will break out around you), sometimes you find yourself spending an hour traveling a short distance because you got hung up in the skirmish. Its got the most "balanced" combat, some people won't like that because it means you're not an unkillable flying god like you are in Just Cause 3 (you're only nearly unkillable lol), but as a result its got some of the most engaging combat that requires the most varied approaches in the series.

Its got weak points (every entry in the series has plenty of weak points), the big weather systems are pretty static and not random in the slightest (they have set locations with literal "on/off" switches once you take over the right facility). Because of the difficulty some missions can be a bit frustrating but the checkpoints are very forgiving so as to mitigate a large amount of that.

Overall this is most likely my second favorite entry in the series and worth a buy for any fan of the series wanting more Rico

Once you start combat anywhere, which gets triggered from the most minute actions, enemies spawn all over you and you'll have to zipline around for 5 minutes and get lucky to get away, because no matter how many you kill, they don't stop coming.

The sound design is surprisingly good and even excellent in some cases. That's the only positive for me though.

122169231.review:
I’ve heard very mixed things about Just Cause 4, but since I liked Just Cause 3 and it was in a bundle, I decided to give it a shot. I agree with the majority. It’s a very mediocre game. It opens with a horrendous looking cutscene that looked worse than anything I remember seeing in the last decade or so. Once I got to the actual gameplay it looked much better, but still not great. I don’t really mind this though since performance is pretty good.

After a short tutorial style mission, you are basically told to go off and cause chaos. That seems to be the majority of the game. No goal or objective or anything, just run around the boring open world mindlessly blowing stuff up. The game does have some story missions, but it rarely tells you where to go for them or how to unlock them. Most of the time you finish one mission and then need to open the map, which feels really poorly designed, actually, all of the UI feels poorly designed. From the map you need to find the mission, then find out what task you need to do to unlock it, which sometimes requires doing several other tasks to unlock other areas of the game. These tasks usually consist of running through a military base and interacting with a few objects. You can shoot enemies and blow stuff up, but you can also usually just run in, click ‘E’ on a few things, and leave. These story missions are fully voice acted with cutscenes, but the cutscenes are so dull I think I’ve found myself zoning out of almost every single one of them.

The explosions and destruction are just as good or better than I remember them being in Just Cause 3, but without any reason to explode stuff it got old fast. The game still has mini challenges, like how far can you drift in a parachute that behave exactly how I remember them in Just cause 3. The game doesn’t really tell you about them, it just keeps track in the background and when you come close to beating a friend or your personal best, you get a mini popup on the side of your screen. I really like these and its really cool to see how I stand in comparison to my friends, but it would have been much nicer if they had integrated it with Steam’s leader boards so I could view stuff without needing to boot up the game. A huge step back is the mini objective’s spread across the map, like the wingsuit stuff. I remember Just Cause 3 giving them a score, adding a competitive aspect to them, but now they are just a binary won or lost. A lot of them also feel a lot worse requiring a specific vehicle to complete. I don’t remember this being the case in Just Cause 3, but even if it was, I don’t like this. They also made it harder to unlock vehicles and weapons, which I do not like.

Maybe it’s just my rose-tinted glasses, but Just Cause 4 doesn’t feel better than Just Cause 3. Either way, it feels like a pretty mediocre game. I probably will still play it more since I already own it and sometimes its fun to mindlessly blow stuff up, but I wouldn’t really recommend anyone go out and buy this.

122122106.review: The game is honestly [i]aggressively[/i] un-fun, which is insane considering that Just Cause 3 was quite a good game. 122118301.review:
awful experience all around, and I'm disappointed this was one of the 'big name' games in humble choice september 2022..

UI is terrible and controlling it is worse (and a noted departure from every game in existence.. ever) the "1" button opens the main game menu - not escape, which opens a different, settings-oriented menu. You can't use escape to get out of menus or skip cutscenes - that's the backspace key... what? The game doesn't tell you that it's possible to skip them either, I had to search that one up.

Cutscenes are awful, dialogue is drab, and at least the opening cutscenes seem to be some kind of 720p pre-rendered trash which looks wonderful on a modern monitor. 

Navigation is unenjoyable, and the tools at your disposal to do so (over short distances), the wingsuit, parachute, and grapple, all seem to work however they feel like at the time.

I haven't played the previous games, so I assume they are a world better because there's no way the Just Cause name has the clout that it does from 4 releases like this. I am surprised that reviews for this are even mixed. I would have strongly expected a slant towards negative sentiment.

121951202.review:
Confusing controls, horrible looking cutscenes, constant combat with no chance to take in the scenery - if the devs aimed for chaos, they got it. Previous games did it better IMO, this game is not worth it, not even in a bundle. Story looks to be the most basic thing of "go there, destroy that, repeat". No depth, characters look bland and shallow, including Rico. 

Game launched in very low resolution the first time and required entire restart to change it. Thought we are past such ancient issues. 

Just Cause 3 made me feel like it is a living world occupied by bad guys.
Just Cause 4 looks like a dead world with constantly ongoing combat and chaos. The moment I was given ability to explore, I was greeted with a singular mission to do. Tried to go over the river and was blasted to pieces by some laser sniper rifle guys. Not fun, not even in the slightest.

If you want to have a true Just Cause experience, just play one of the previous titles. This one aint worth it.

121917664.review:
This game is utterly atrocious. It has the most archaic keybindings I've seen in 5 years on any game, let alone one priced this high. Half of the terrible keys can't even be rebound, yet they've managed to make the most complicated imaginable series of settings for every fathomable category, yet none of the bindings are what you need. Picture the complexity of arma paired with the simplicity of roblox. On top of that, the game itself is horribly buggy and terribly designed right off the start. The plot is the exact same thing it always is, but with a new coat of paint. The graphics are marginally better than the second game. 

This 'game' is just an utter scam. It's the Madden of third person shooters. It makes even the newest Gears of War games look like bouts of divine creativity. The maps are always identical to one another and offer no variety. The worlds are always empty and devoid of life. The AI is always horrible and bland. The combat is always horribly uninspired and boring, offering nothing unique at all. Animations are practically recycled from the old games, just like everything else within this horrid experience. 

The first real mission is an escort mission, which have always been the worst thing to ever exist within these barely passable games. They always involve horrible pathing from the drivers, terrible map design that leads to glitches and the vehicle getting stuck, and laughable enemy spawns that you can literally see. The FIRST mission in this 7 0 D O L L A R G A M E is an escort mission where the car gets completely turned around 3 times in a row and then breaks, getting stuck for zero purpose. Full health and at every tutorial ridden junction it stops at, the AI fails to move on when you clear the path and just sits there. 

The tutorials are even terrible, forcing you into buggier sequences where you're forced to jump through their terribly conceived hoops just to progress. The tutorial introducing Grappling hook loadouts, which might have been fun were it not made by apes slapping a keyboard while starving, was so horribly broken that it locked me out of weapon switching. I closed out of the menu accidentally while trying to do it and the game decided that I was no longer worthy of playing. I couldn't grapple anymore, couldn't switch weapons, couldn't reload, and restarting my objective didn't fix that. 

Every popup in this game, of which there are many for some reason, makes this game lag. You're constantly getting popups about achievements, milestones, feats, or just your score compared to your steam friends who also play this game. Even if you have NONE, it still pops up non stop and the entire game freezes every single time this happens. I'm on a 2080 with an i9 and this game can't handle its own popups. The frame rate is stable, but the entire game freezes every time you kill anyone because you get a popup telling you about it. 

I have not seen such a blatant scam of a game in ages. This feels like it was made by a team only kept motivated by indentured servitude and the knowledge that their families will die without what little money they receive. I got this from Humble Bundle and I feel horrendously scammed. This game having even mixed ratings, let alone positive ones, is the prime example of how and why the gaming industry has become a joke so old that everyone's tired of even thinking about it. 

What a fucking joke.

121501302.review:
I hate leaving bad reviews... (warning: possible spoilers)

Just Cause 4 is the weakest game in the series on many levels. Here's some of the worst issues:

1. Story: ...or the lack of one. You get a quick glimpse of the main bad guy at the start of the game, a quick exchange with his second-in-command a short while later, then nothing. No interaction with the enemy until the very end of the game. There is some interactions with friendly NPCs, but 90% of the game is non-interactive. 

2. Missions/Goals: There is a main quest line but it is incredibly brief. However, to perform some of these quests, the game forces you to go out and clear some regions. Clearing regions is the only real game play here.

3. Weapons/Vehicles/Tools: To be honest, I played the entire way through with the automatic rifle I started with and a grenade launcher. Every other weapon had limitations that made them nonviable. As always, the grappling hook and call for gun/vehicle drops and location drops makes up the bulk of world traversal.

4. Graphics/Characters/Environments/Etc.: Very, very dated. Feels and looks like a lot of recycled assets from previous versions.

This game ruined my faith in the Just Cause series. I'm going to be very cautious when/if I see JC5 drop here on Steam. I'll watch game play videos and read a few reviews, but I won't buy it just on brand recognition.

119862684.review:
[b]Buy this on sale only if you've already played Just Cause 3, otherwise buy that.[/b]

This is a strange game, it's got a really good world, some decent customizability of the grappling hook and the destruction and physics feel better than ever. The challenges around the world are much more fun than the ones in JC3. The gameplay mostly feels good and satisfying but something went horribly wrong somewhere with this game.

The mission design is for the most part absolute garbage. Instead of progressing by destroying everything in a given area, you instead have to do a mission in each area. This could maybe have worked, but unfortunately someone thought it was a good idea to make most missions the worst kind mission, a kind of mission universally hated by everyone: escort missions. Usually the targets you're escorting are bullet sponges and don't ever die, but you have to babysit them while they use their roomba path finding to eventually get where they're going. A few of these can be frustrating, when you're tasked to defend certain fragile radio towers from 360 degrees of infinitely spawning tanks, helicopters and infrantry, but there are probably only two or three of these.

Luckily, there are not that many of these frontline missions, but that leaves us the rest of the content, which is mostly various challenges and some side missions. Most of this is pretty good, with the exception of training missions, which again usually include some sort of escort mechanic, but more lazily put together than the story and frontline missions. Usually it goes like this: Pick up two guys in a vehicle and take them with you to destroy some things while they watch. If they left your vehicle make sure to land/park on their toes so they only run around like headless chickens for half a minute instead of two before getting back in. Rinse and repeat three times.

On top of all this there are a number of smaller problems, including but not limited to:
[list]
[*]The military/black hand has no more heat levels, they're now simply either looking for you or not, which causes some strange things to happen like tanks and helicopters responding to minor incidents. Another problem with their response is that it's no longer possible to fight them off to lose your heat like you could in JC3. These things combined makes the military feel more like an annoyance than a fun mechanic to interact with.
[*]The interface is bad. It feels like they made it for a game pad and then told someone who has never used a keyboard or game pad before to translate game pad buttons to keyboard keys. Luckily the controls in-game are mostly fine.
[*]Since you're liberating whole areas at a time, essentially everything except for large military bases has no process of liberation, no mission, no things you need to destroy, making most places pretty forgettable.
[/list]

119753248.review:
when this game was announced, i was super hyped. by that stage every instalment from the just cause series got better and better, and i was hoping that 4 would follow that trend but it seemed that for every minor improvement they added, they would remove a feature from 3 that made it awesome. on its own merit the game itself can be fun, but compared to 3 its not that great. i do want to give it some due respect. the graphics are good, the word and weather are interesting to look at, the enemy ai is smarter and there's a lot more variety to them, the physics are visually and technically impressive, and the guns feel a lot better to use.
now let me give you 20 reasons why this game is a pile of peepee.
1. the world may be more varied with a lot of attention to detail then 3's but it feels very bland and empty, 3 did have this issue but not as much as 4 and navigating through it can be a slug
2. the new weather systems add nothing to gameplay other then "oh cool a tornado"
3. the story has a much more serious tone then 3 but in turn it makes it come off as corny and slow
4. just cause 3 starts with a sick montage, just cause 4 starts with a mindless exposition dump
5. they removed c4
6. the bad guy is a cliche rich man, just cause 3's villain was a cold, ruthless and yet lazy dictator
7. the secondary fire makes each gun feel uniqe but it kinda feels like an after thought as i would always forget about it.
8. you cant blow up bridges
9. they removed c4
10. the plot structure is go here, meet new person, do things for them. build a tool to stop weather thing, done. and that happens 4 times
11. you cant liberate towns
12. the atheistic went into a more si-fi rout which is more of a personal preference thing but i like the idea of a one man army going up against an actual army rather then teched up soldiers
13. the characters are far less likeable then in three
14. the plot starts with a strong sense of finale and personal connections but ends up devolving into 'this happened once, remember just cause 1? and this is the next game"
15. the army of chaos feels more like a sales point. its there to give chaos points an actually reason for existing but it removes the liberation of bases and instead gives incentives taking over land. this adds nothing to gameplay or mission structure. what if they added big battles that you can fight, win or loose in, what if you could train your army to be better and have them help liberate towns. in the end it feels more in the way then anything as you have to use them to move forward in the story
16. they removed c4
17. the ui is a mess
18. the different grapple options are kinda cool but mostly forgettable as its easiest to probably just stick with the retracting one. its mainly there to send goats and cows flying through the air
19. probably the main problem, they changed the way you liberate bases, instead of blowing everything up, you insted have to do a mission that range from escorting someone, breaking prisoners out, hacking something, ect, kinda like in just cause 2 this is so incredibly stupid. in 3 it gave you so much freedom in the ways you can blow things up and that was essentially the main gameplay. in 4 they hold you arm back and forces you to do stuff you don't want to do, when what you actually want to do (explosions) just sits there teasing you.
20. why oh god did they remove the c4
in the end i wonder why i got this rather then just playing just cause 3

The Story was very boring. The main "Villain" appeared like, 2 times. I literally can't even remember his name there wasn't like any fun way to kill him either, he dies in a cutscene. 
In just cause 1 you jump out of a plane and put a bomb on Mendoza as you're both free falling 
In just cause 2 you fight Baby Panai on 3 nuclear missiles having a gunfight while also disarming them 
In just cause 3 Di Ravello appears several times in cutscenes, theres all this propaganda of him and you have a fight in a volcano against a high tech gunship with a gold paint on it in a volcano and you actually have the option to shoot him or to not shoot him in which he kills himself.
And here the dude like, dies in his private jet.

Then the Heat System which is gone. In the all the other games you have heat and you would have different tier of units come after you as more elite troops and vehicles are put against you.
Here theres none instead you just fight the regular recruits, there are all these unique enemy types yet they only appear in missions and honestly I rarely ever saw them which is disappointing. Also I found in just cause 3 that there were like unuiqe enemy types for every vehicle. There was a specific unit for every vehicle. Tanks bikes and helicopters.

The ammo is also a bit of a problem in my opinion, I feel like I could never use most weapons since the enemies that use them are rare and instead of just going of weapon type so if an enemy had a shotgun like the pump action one and I had the automatic one I could just pick up that ammo instead of having to get it from the exact weapon. So I would always just carry like the regular SMG and assault rifle with me. Also I don't understand why Rico wouldn't have a sidearm. In the all the games he has dual wield pistols yet here only 2 weapons. I had some fun with the railgun and if I wanted more ammo I could always just fast travel to the crash site where I could always find plenty of ammo.

The grappling was very interesting however it is very confusing for starters and I also got confused.

The Challenges were extremely disappointing like it wasn't the same anymore. For wingsuit you just have to through like 3 rings in a few seconds, unlike the old one which was very frustrating but thats what made it so cool, always trying to get the max score and pushing yourself to the limit. I mean the gears that Rico could get were very fun. Things like homing grenades and explosives with boosters on them. I feel like Rico really wasn't as powerful as he was in Just cause 3. 

The only cool part was the agency DLC with the hoverboard challenges. You had a challenge for every submarine and 1 very long course which kind of reminded me of the old challenges and at least they brought back the liberation system.

The liberation system is very sad.
There was like this main base in which you had some thing to do and this wasn't very interesting like they are all the same.
I really wouldev like to just destroy all of these massive bases and leave everything destroyed instead of having everything respawn every time. The only reason they are even there was just so you could cause chaos to gain "Squads" to fully take over an area. Destroying the weather control station missions were the only ones I liked honestly.
When I was playing just cause 3 I liked to liberate every base in the island region and then start the missions which would mean I always had an easier time with every mission so the rebels were always there to cover my back and in some missions I could just walk in freely with no one shooting at me.

118904456.review:
I really really tried to like this game. Loved JC 2 and JC 3. This one is trying to take itself too seriously. 
Graphics: 
vomit looking yellow green trees, muddy brown rivers, a sky that looks polluted, even Rico somehow looks worse, its visually unappealing and no amount of reshading has helped. It seriously makes you wish they just stuck with JC 3 graphics.
Sound: 
The sound is ok
Gameplay: 
The pc interface for navigating menus is flat out bad, the worst on earth ever. One would expect a few constants that most other games use: M for map, I for inventory, etc, ...but no, it's 1 for the menu then you have to look because if you're not on the map you have to see if you need to press 2 to go to the map or 3, they change the mapping. Just what one wants to worry about in a JC title, how to navigate a rediculous UI. I don't know if remapping really matters, I found the thought of it so daunting I just plain don't care to worry about it.
Ammo is always running out, limited, hard to find. The enemies of course are suicidal and never run out of ammo but you're constantly constantly having to worry about finding more guns to switch to and more ammo.
Mods? well unfortunately the game is so unpopular the modding community has pretty much overlooked this title, don't expect any mods that will fix what will you find broken.
What am I supposed to be doing?  Just like JC 3 there's no mini map, it would be preferable if they had one and then had an option to turn it off. But JC3 is still way superior, I was never too confused in that game about what I should be doing. It had personality and a flow. This JC 4 has none.  And going into the Map doesn't help me understand what I'm supposed to be doing. I can't really quite explain this so let me explain how I felt. I found myself asking myself what am I supposed to be doing over and over, I don't even know why I'm being so murderous and why I care for this "cause" they are fighting for, they haven't given me a reason to care....it's lost me and no game really does that to me like this one did. It SUCKS when the game feels empty like that.

Quality of life and the final word: This game is very visually unappealing, janky UI, strangely not light hearted, and too many unfun gaming elements like nutcase UI and mapping, constant ammo probs and plot confusion.

Send the game designers a message: do not buy this downgrade to the JC series. It's not what you came here for and you will leave unsatisfied. Play JC 3, it is way funner and that is the main point of playing a game isn't it?

118883214.review:
Just Cause 4 was not what I had expected. I originally thought that JC4 would just be more JC3, but I was wrong. It sucks that I have to give this game a bad review. I kinda wish there was an in between for the yes and no.

 One thing that I did not enjoy was the liberation system. In JC3, there were multiple towns and bases that you could liberate. Those were fun and made you feel like a badass. JC4 on the other hand, has you do strikes on bigger bases instead. I expected the strikes to be fun, but most of them contain the same objectives. I understand that in JC3, it was the same objectives as well: destroy, but those objectives were fun. This game's objectives is just flipping breakers and a few other things that are repeated. After that, you just advance your frontlines into the next area you liberated (if its adjacent).

The game is definitely worth the price on sale because you can get the game and all the DLC for under $20, and that's a steal. Overall, JC4 is a decent game but just isn't the same as three. Also, Danger Rising is an actually good content DLC. The other two, I couldn't finish because they just weren't that fun.

TLDR: just get the game and all the DLC when it's on sale. (also, Danger Rising is cool)

118494943.review:
I love 3rd person action games especially the ones where you just blow stuff up.  Mercenaries 1 and 2 were some of my favorites.  I really liked Just Cause 3.  It was a great game to turn your brain off and just blow stuff up.  Taking out each base at a time as I improved my movement and weapons was great.  So it was really a surprise to find out how much I didn't like this one.  They ruined.. well.. everything.  The things that pop out in my head in no particular order.
- infinite enemies harass you at all times no matter what.  Not in a fun way, more like being attacked by really weak bees but instead of stingers they just wear on your interest by buzzing around you.
- Its no longer about destroying bases and big explosions... which i thought was the whole pitch of the JC games.  Seems like stunts are the focus now.  I mean destroying bases isnt even a thing any more.
- The whole movement thing doesnt feel good any more.  I found it impossible to stay in the air with the wing suit unlike the 3rd one.
- 3rd game was easy to grapple what you want like enemy planes but I found it more difficult in this game.
- Driving isnt fun, cant put my finger on why.
- The map is huge but completely empty of anything interesting.
- Objectives are not clear as to what they are or why you should do them or what reward you will get.
- You start with all abilities.  There is no unlocking, no leveling.
- The weaponry is not interesting.
- The grappling hook was turned into a gimmick and made incredibly complicated.
- The wing suit is a nightmare.  I'm unsure why but it just doesnt feel smooth and its hard to even go in the direction you want.  Grapple hooking for speed just seems to send you into the ground.

I would just recommend playing Just Cause 3.

This game is fun for maybe 20 minutes, but it's full of extremely frustrating issues.

- Some of the transmitters I'm supposed to protect are always stuck at zero (the transmission bar). It doesn't move at all.

- You have to pay extra if you want the jetpack, which you get early on in JC3. In this game, you never that jetpack if you buy the game. You have to buy a deluxe version.

- The water ... the waves a mile away move faster than the waves 50 feet away.

- Flammable vehicles -  Half of the missions where you must escort someone somewhere in a vehicle, or drive a boat to a harbor and keep it there for a certain duration, or drive a boat off a waterfall... If you play the mission for 25 minutes, then your boat catches fire because some other boat drives into you (they drive into your boat, 10 out of 10 times, several boats at once). When this happens (and it ALWAYS happens), JC4 will ask "Retry/Quit." Click "Retry" and you START at your latest checkpoint WITH YOUR VEHICLE ON FIRE. Ten seconds later your vehicle explodes. "Mission Failed: Vehicle Destroyed." Clicking "Retry" is futile. You have to start the mission at the beginning and do the same boring part (it eventually becomes boring the 15th time you spend 25 minutes carefully driving your boat). Then it happens again. "Retry?" Why even ask? Don't start me at a checkpoint with this precious vehicle I need to protect, in flames.

- Seems like every 10 minutes I was googling what I need to do next. With Just Cause 3, I don't recall ever doing that. I was engrossed in Just Cause 3 and looked forward to liberating more towns and outposts. After playing Just Cause 4 for a couple hours, I never looked forward to playing Just Cause 4.

- The map is always zoomed in. You can never see the entire map. Why in the world would the designers do that? To make it feel bigger?

Just Cause 3 was fun. I loved it.

Just Cause 4 added stress and frustration to my life.

Sadly, I'm only 4 hours in and I don't think it's worth the time to complete. JC2 and 3 had Rico as the lone hero Dictator Removal Specialist. Here he's a heavily armed Doordash driver, being sent on missions that rely on comms, while any non-mission activity doesn't count. So you never look at the map and think "hmm What shall I blow up now..." because there's no point. The enemy has infinite respawn/rebuild and you can only free the map through scripted missions. 
Following on from breaking the open world nature, the cutscenes and story were less involving than the original Ghost Recon mission briefings. The map mechanics for progress are obtrusive and irritating, in a way that JC2 and 3 never were. Also why did he throw away the Bavarium powered wingsuit? Suit was cash.
I understand what the graphics are trying to do, having got Rage2, capture the humidity and sunlight/shade of the jungle and they do that extremely well up close, along with the trash and world-making detais, but rendering at distance gives the jungle a kind of impressionistic filter, while the unaliased text gives an unpolished feel. JC2 and 3 had great water and boat feel. JC4 boats and water brought back PS2 memories.
I can't even say that "I want to like it". I don't like it, it doesn't have the magic or humor of the previous 2.

117869808.review:
I had forgotten about this game for years since I played a free version years ago in 2020. Only after revisiting Just Cause 3 did I decide to revisit this game as well. 

This game is nothing compared to its predecessor.

-Liberation, a core mechanic in Just Cause 3 was removed from this game. Why? People might've said it was repetitive but it was nowhere near as repetitive as the missions you do in this game. Every town and base was different and made you use a different strategy, it also gave you a reason to explore the map and would create some epic firefights. In this game, you have to hack this, hack that, wait for some timer or let someone else hack something. Very boring and repetitive. Don't even get me started on that transmitter defense mission, it took me 5 tries to complete. If it ain't broke, don't fix it!

-As mentioned by many other reviewers, graphics seem to be downgraded heavily compared to the previous game, even running on the recommended setting could not top the beauty that Just Cause 3 had. The water in particular also sucks, it's a shame because JC3 had beautiful water. Even Just Cause 2 had better water and that was a 2010 game. The water also lacks any physics as well. Things like explosions and basic destruction are also toned down, you can only blow up certain bridges and explosions don't look as nice as in the previous game. I understand people had performance issues with Just Cause 3, but that is no excuse to downgrade it this much, especially on PC.

-No reason to destroy stuff or explore the map. Because of the removal of the aforementioned liberation mechanic, blowing up things, something Just Cause is known for, is not required at all and is a waste of time because it will respawn later. This also means you have no incentive to explore the map, all you have to do is the boring base missions.

-Ammo limits on vehicles. Come on, this is a Just Cause game. I swear they only added this to piss people off.

-No grenades. No C4. No dual handguns that made Rico look so badass. 

-Cutscenes look like they were rendered on an Xbox 360. 

-No proper day/night cycle like in the previous games. Medici looked spectacular at sunset. Actually I don't recall ever seeing this game at night outside of missions.

-Story is boring. I'm not saying Just Cause 3 had GTA 5 / RDR 2 levels of storytelling but at least that game had memorable characters (like Mario Frigo) and had a good dictator, Di Ravello. The game balanced serious moments with comedic and funny ones. As another reviewer put it, "at least JC3 acknowledged Di Ravello's presence and he was a thought out character." Meanwhile, none of the characters in this game are particularly memorable and the main dictator, Oscar Espinosa is only seen twice, once at the beginning, and once at the end. In addition, the story is now too serious, the comedic moments are gone. 

-No introduction and no final boss fight. JC2 and 3 both had introductions that were fun and epic. Firestarter playing and then launching rockets off a plane was badass. In this game, there is no introduction, it cuts to the chase immediately.
Also, there is no final boss fight, it is a cutscene instead. Fighting Panay and Di Ravello was fun, I don't understand why we couldn't have the same here.

-Heat is not fun anymore. In the previous game, you had actual heat levels (1 to 5) and the military would chase you. As the heat increased, they gradually bring more and more reinforcements, and then send in helicopters and tanks to try and stop you. It felt amazing blowing up every soldier trying to chase you.
In this game however, there are no more heat levels. It wouldn't be bad if the game didn't spam Black Hand units behind you. As the heat rises, helicopters and tanks show up like they did in the previous game, however in this game jets will also attack you. What's the big deal you ask? Well, there is no reliable way to fight back against these jets, they are overpowered too, usually almost killing you. To add insult to injury, the game will not stop spamming enemies and spawning them wherever you can't see, often right next to you. If you are in the air, fighter jets will spawn instantly. They somehow managed to swarm a remote island far from the mainland with their cars tanks and helicopters. Also, it breaks the immersion of a revolution when the Black Hand can chase you deep into Army of Chaos territory, which makes no sense.
At least in Just Cause 3 they spawned realistically, you could see the military driving down the road to intercept you.

-Frontlines are a classic example of 'good in theory, bad in practice'. The only practical use I found was to farm Chaos.

-I didn't even bother with challenges. Yes, they're as bad as people say they are. 

-Just Cause 3 had a beautiful and vibrant color tone that made it so nice to look at. In my opinion its beauty rivals big dogs like GTA 5. Just Cause 4 lacks this and the game looks pretty bland because of it.

-No incentive to drive vehicles. Just Cause 3 had the 'chop shop' challenges, allowing you to collect all sorts of vehicles. This game lacks that. Why drive when you can fly or fast travel?

-Vehicle physics suck, worse than the previous games actually. Don't get me started on motorcycles. 

-Map feels empty. Towns and cities don't feel alive. In Just Cause 3 towns felt alive, after liberating them there would even  be fireworks and street musicians performing.

-Enemy AI sucks. Some enemies are bullet sponges while others are just plain annoyances. 

-AI actually sucks in general. I could not complete several missions because some NPC wanted to go somewhere else instead of where the mission told me to go.

-The map is less interesting than previous games. I did explore the map, but I found it to way more boring than exploring Medici or Panau. The desert for example is nearly empty.

-Base liberation missions are literally just copy paste recycled missions. 

-UI is trash.

-I nearly forgot about the disasters. They are only used in a few missions and most are then never seen again. Unacceptable, considering how much they featured in this game's marketing. Literally every trailer was just random dubstep music with a tornado or something.

-All DLC's are garbage and are a waste of time and money, except Danger Rising, which is surprisingly okay.

So, what about the pros?

-You can blow up stuff?

-Weapons are, alright?

-The map is, there?

TLDR/In conclusion this game was a major step backwards for its franchise, it's no wonder that this game was forgotten after about a year and that nobody, not even me remembers this game. Please, do yourself a favor and get Just Cause 3. You can thank me later. It's such a shame because this game had so much potential.

117614471.review:
Just Cause 4 is a great game in many respects, but it is unfortunately a departure in some ways from some of the best gameplay mechanics of its predecessors. Just Cause 4 is still a lot of fun jumping back into the shoes of Rico and wreaking havoc with an impressive arsenal. It is always fun to jump in and pretend to be an 80's action hero, shooting up enemy camps and setting off explosions left and right. The series of games has been a ton of fun to play over the years so I was super excited to play 4 when it came out. Just Cause 4 adds some very interesting weather effects to the gameplay that keep the story interesting.
     It was still hilarious fun at times, but there are a few game mechanics that were a departure from how the previous games worked that did put a damper on what could have been even better. If you've played any of the other Just Cause games, the way that you would usually liberated town and bases was by taking out specific targets and objectives in each location. But this game changes this mechanic so that your now have a "Chaos" meter that needs to be filled to liberate an area or region. This mechanic is probably intended to speed up the game to not seem as tedious, but it is such a departure from the old system that it felt sad to not have to go to each base and town to liberate them. It sort of feels like a disservice to the intricate locations of the game that are very well designed and modeled, but that many players probably won't see because the mechanics don't incentivize players to go explore as much any more. Maybe it's just me, but this was a pretty big let-down for me from what we had come to expect from the Just Cause games.
     Still a pretty fun game that I would rate at a 7/10.

117609123.review:
It's an alright game for the price it is when on sale. As mentioned in lots of other reviews, it's a big disappointment they changed how you take over regions and settlements now compared to the previous games. It definitely isn't as fun to what is basically do one of the same type of 3-4 missions per area you want to liberate, and then click on it on the map to liberate. There is no feeling of progression like in the previous games, where you have to work to find all the things to destroy before you can take that settlement away from the bad guys.

The grappling hook mods (of which there are many) didn't really seem to be all that important to me. If you have read about how over-complicated it is, and that seems to scare you away, just know that I went through the whole game without actually changing any mods on the different types throughout the whole game. It is not required to beat it.

The DLC adds quite a bit of things to do in the game, with one of them being overly frustrating at times, which is the Los Demonios DLC. It is very easy to die, and takes quite a bit of patience to complete. It does take patience to complete this one, but it is possible. Overall I was glad it was over when I was done with all the missions for this one.

The Dare Devils of Destruction DLC I am still working on, but is basically driving on a course with guns mounted to your vehicle, while you try to rack up your score by shooting targets/other cars while keeping in a time limit. It seems alright so far and is a nice change of pace for when you need a break from the open world shenanigans you can get into.

Lastly, the Danger Rising DLC adds in a hoverboard you can use, and gives you missions to take down the agency on submarines located in the sea around the world. I have read there are time trials you can do for the hoverboard on these, but haven't attempted any of them yet. 

I have seen complaints about having limited ammo on flying vehicles. This doesn't seem to be too much of a problem as you can just request a drop for another flying vehicle and you get a full amount of ammo on the new one you just dropped. If you want to save time, you can just try to hijack an enemies vehicle, which usually isn't too hard.

All in all, if you want some more Just Cause, and are sick to death of playing Just Cause 2 and 3, this one will make do until the 5th comes around (hopefully with the old settlement and liberating stuff compared to this one). At the price you can get it for sale nowadays, and you aren't trying to be overly critical about every little thing in the game, there is at least some fun to be had by playing it. I know I don't regret buying and playing it at least for the sale price.

117430271.review:
I'm a big fan of the Just Cause games but was wary upon seeing the mixed reviews. As it turns out, the more critical takes were correct. Imagine previous Just Cause games but bad and that's this game. The joy of exploring the world and taking settlements and bases one by one is gone. Instead, you go into a base, complete a repetitive side mission (there are about 3 actual varieties), and use the frontline system to just take the entire region. Causing chaos is honestly secondary and not very important. You blow stuff up, it respawns and you just do it again. Squads are gained without even trying and some regions even give you extra squads without having to cause chaos. The destruction, the completionist aspect of the game is lost.

Oh, and remember all those cool races and unique challenges and side missions? Imagine reducing them to a whopping 1 to 3 ring race with no real challenge and you've got what this game calls "content". Side quests are also highly repetitive and forgettable. There aren't many of them either.

I don't have an issue with games trying to move in a new direction as long as the new is better than the old. That, unfortunately, is not the case here. Do yourself a favor and don't buy this game. Go get the other Just Cause games instead and you will have a much better time, I promise.

117425506.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

116963716.review:
JC4 is an extremely fun game. BUT, it is pretty janky.

I feel like they forgot how to program physics properly after JC3, and they wanted to nerf the wing suit from one of two awesome JC3 DLCs as much as possible. I don't know what they did to screw up a Just Cause game with the size of the location we're in this time when they made JC3 which had a much larger map.

In terms of Story, Characters, Gunplay, Vehicles, and Concept... they did a good job on this one. What they got wrong was Physics, and the Control Responsiveness. JC3 had the better of both.

They added in new tether specific gadgets, which is fun.

For those who've played JC3 with the DLC, let me lower your expectations. The wingsuit no longer has awesome homing missiles, and now shoots 4 missiles that go in a single selected direction at once. There is no machine gun, and there is no dodging SAMs (though they eliminated the need to dodge SAMs). There is only the Brawler Mech, it can only punch, dash, jump, grab, and make cute beeping "honk" noises, and the gravity grab is very unresponsive. There is no orbital lightning laser gun, just a gun that shoots a short and seemingly ineffective beam of electricity (with a grenade launcher that basically creates a small temporary storm to strike an area with a smattering of lightning).

What I can say that I love about this game is the new tether gadgets that add new features that all have a set of effects you can use to change how one of three "Tether loadouts" behaves. 

My biggest complaint about this game is that the game itself is seemingly free but you HAVE to buy it with DLC and you don't even get to select each individual DLC you want... you just have to get the one that has the most of what you want, and that'd probably be the complete edition. Enemies now immediately alert all others and their headquarters without the need for one to call it in with their radio, which frustrates me and kills the immersion. They also added a new hoverboard that goes across water and has magnetic rails you can ride on in only a few very specific locations... and has no other use than what the game teaches you to do with it. If you run into something, it'll lose all momentum. If you have too much momentum and take a sharp turn, you'll ride it off the intended path. You can't do tricks with it, you can't upgrade it, and you HAVE to propel it with some form of momentum or your grapple hook. It is single-handedly the worst item they could've added in my opinion.

To the devs, in the words of a man talking to a missile while riding it... F&%K YOU!!

116737031.review:
If you have played any of the previous titles, then there won't be much surprise to this. There are more weapons and tools available this time around. The map is large and varied, which at times becomes a pleasure to traverse. This game is heavily about mobility with the grappling hook, and chaos. With no pun to be intended, this game revolves around chaos which can be both good and bad. It will keep encounters fresh with lots of explosions to watch.

The downside to this is, this can also turn against you. If you aren't aware of your environment, pieces of rubble or explosive devices will collide and be your demise. This is offset from a frequent and forgiving checkpoint system. In addition, guns don't really have much variation in purpose, so there are no upgrades or things to seek to optimize weaponry. Just pick up a gun and shoot. 

Vehicles come in a wide variety, but unless equipped with weapons they are a sideshow. Controls are not great in vehicles but manageable. 

Story is nothing incredible, but keeps the pacing and flow going. It would be noted that the DLC is good if you are seeking an increase in tools (hoverboard, crossbow, vehicles etc). None of the DLCs was incredible by any means, but served their purposes. The demon DLC was more annoying if anything, but the crossbow it comes with is a powerful weapon. It is important to note these DLC are available from the start, so you can use in conjunction with main campaign.

Graphically it runs well, and looks good for the amount that is happening on screen.

Overall I would recommend this if you enjoy the prior titles or enjoy open world chaos. If you are new to the franchise this would be a recommended buy on sale including any dlc that may be speculated.

116592235.review:
Just Cause 4 is certainly a contender for the worst game I've ever played, especially given how much I love the previous two games. 

It's essentially a downgrade from Just Cause 3 in almost every way, despite being mostly made with reused assets - first of all, it reneges on the destruction based gameplay, instead opting to structure the game around poorly designed and eye-wateringly repetitive missions. Destruction is still there, but there's no incentive to engage with it beyond just wanting to blow stuff up for fun. The range of weapons and their unique abilities are nice, but combat is ridiculous thanks to the disparity between enemies, with some being paper-thin annoyances, and others incredibly spongey and overpowered. The controls are finicky and unresponsive, especially when it comes to mucking around with the grappling hook and all of its novelty options. Even when story was never much the focus of the previous games, the writing really takes a dive here, to the point where the plot is pretty much non-existent beyond "Rico shows up and is now in charge of a rebel army", and dialogue is painfully bad too. Even on its highest settings the game looks absolutely awful, undoubtedly worse than 3 and possibly even 2 in a few areas, and cutscenes are all rendered on a lower setting as well as being locked at a low frame rate. The DLC packs exacerbate some of the game's worst aspects in the driving, combat and writing respectively, but at least Danger Rising tries to resuscitate the destruction based progression at the last hurdle. There's a couple more saving graces to be found, for one the open world is large, diverse and well-populated with a variety of locations, even if many of them feel reused from one another, and amazingly I ran into very little in the way of bugs and glitches, but overall the game is just a plain old mess that feels like it was made without an ounce of passion. 

3/10

116410729.review:
You might be asking, why am I writing a review for a 3+ years old game that received a lukewarm welcome and was pretty much forgotten right from the get-go. Well, I’m gonna do you one better – why does JC4 even exist? Looking back at previous releases, it feels like the journey of our favorite firestarter Rico Rodriguez has come to a natural conclusion by the end of JC3. After having deposed several ruthless dictators around the world, Rico set on to liberate his own home country of Medici. That’s where the story ends, at least that’s where it should’ve end.

But, Avalanche execs demanded more Just Cause, so here we have the fourth installment. The story has never been the highlight of the series, often being just a backdrop to the trademark joyridin‘, jet hijackin‘, tank destroyin‘, missile evadin‘, air divin‘, chaos risin‘ mayhem. Which is more puzzling considering JC4’s 180 storyline focus. Okay, maybe not a complete 180 – more like an 85° turn. Without spoiling much (not that there is a lot to spoil), Rico journeys to a small South American island country of Solis ruled by yet another authoritarian mogul, whose name I quickly forgot after the intro cutscene.

Not that my last 2 surviving brain cells are at fault since you see the main villain exactly 2 times during the entire game! Once at the beginning and once at the end. It’s not like you saw Sebastiano Di Ravello (JC3’s villain) every second mission, but at least the game acknowledged his presence and he felt like a thought out character. There’s also his lieutenant, who happens to be a sister of the head of the rebel army, however, nothing noteworthy ever comes out of this relationship.

I forgot to mention stuff with Rico’s father, then again, he is as prevalent in the story as generic soldier #0468 I threw off the bridge with my grappling hook that time.

So the story sucks, but you don’t play JC for the story. You wanna know how’s the gameplay. As I have mentioned it’s still the same ol‘ helicopter crashin‘, military base bombardin‘, civil infrastructure demolishin‘ fun. Only with several major changes to the core gameplay. For the uninitiated, JC’s primary gameplay mechanic has always been slowly but surely taking over each region until The Big Baddie loses control of the country. You do this by – causing chaos. You do that by – liberating towns and cities, overtaking military installations and blowing ♥♥♥♥ up. Nice and simple.

Only in JC4, you do none of that. It seems like the devs at Avalanche have lost focus of what made their series, well, fun. Maybe they’ve wanted to adress the issue of repetitiveness of JC, only this isn’t sufficient remedy. In JC3, if you wanted to attack a military base, you’d get in your high-power helicopter and blow up every piece of military equipment you come across. Once you do, the base belongs to the rebel army. Trying the same approach in JC4 is completely meaningless since everything you blow up will respawn after time – as if you weren’t even there.

Instead, you are supposed to complete missions named Region Strikes. These fall into several pre-set categories – all tremendously unimaginative, unexciting, repetitive, copy-paste, simply boring. Escorting prisoners, hacking a security console, protecting an NPC while they hack a security console or protecting a point of interest while some hacking is going on elsewhere. Most involve waiting until a bar fills up. After that, you send rebels to invade a region and they do the job for you... *explosionless sigh*

The rest of the game plays out in this very same basic rhythm. The side missions are not much to talk about either. JC3’s challenges such as destruction derbys, land, air and sea races, have been replaced by what I think someone with severe brain damage considers challenge. „Race through these 3 rings“ or „pass through this ring in a specific vehicle“ are dotted around the map Ubisoft open world style. There are more stimulating events such as discovering lost tombs, however, they never unlock anything substantial.

That brings me to another gripe – no upgrade system like the one in JC3. In its place, you have MODs. Completing challenges mentioned above nets you points you can then spend unlocking various modifications for Rico’s signature grappling hook‘s 3 primary functions – air lifter, retractor and booster. All of them serve the purpose one‘d expect. It’s a shame you rarely need them, if ever. There’s barely any gameplay puzzles designed for specific grappling hook modifications. Once you unlock them, you will forget about them.

The same goes for the much praised extreme weather system. Tornadoes, sandstorms or massive lightning storms are delegated to a handful of story missions, where they take a form of a scripted event. Not to imply it isn’t fun to glide around a tornado, pierce through a sandstorm with a train or dodge a lightning bolt – the game shines at those moments. I just wish the game would’ve done more with them and take advantage of the extreme weather it proudly boasts about.

JC4 puts front and center features the devs didn’t flesh out. Just like The Black Hand, Rico’s „toughest enemies yet“, as the trailers brag, turn out to be more of the same. The AI never utilized clever tactics, flanked me or surprised me. The only challenge The Black Hand poses is in their sheer numbers.

Pros:
+ Extreme weather
+ Diverse biomes

Cons:
- A visual downgrade compared to JC3
- Lack of compelling story
- Repetitive mission design
- No upgrade system
- No real challenge

Rating: 4/10

116059958.review:
The good:
Graphics, sounds, voices, cutscenes, landscapes, a diverse world... A lot of work went into that. That's what makes it at least fun for a few hours.

The bad:
It's just... Empty. You keep blasting around, having fun with the parachute and the wingsuit, and hunt for story pieces... But everything is the same - just shoot and kill everything, until the thing says you're done. And then (other than in previous games) if you revisit the location, everything is built back up again! So it doesn't even matter. And as soon as you set foot in enemy territory, the sky is suddenly buzzing with ridiculous drones, planes and enemy helicopters, that came out of nowhere.

It's also buggy. I've experienced multiple CTD's, have had to reinstall because fullscreen didn't work any more, have had movement keys stuck, have glitched through vehicles, suddenly died out of nowhere, fell down from cliffs without taking a single hit, been unable to open or close the parachute... And then there's the servers being offline so I can't play, and then constantly mismatched cloud saves. It's just a mess. And that's all within 5 hours of playtime.

So yeah, it's a nope for me. I got it on sale for less than 10 bucks and what's 10 buck for a few hours of relative fun, so hey you can give it a try on a good sale, but the frustration about how badly the thing is put together just wins out.

115831279.review:
(dev 1) do you know what folks love about Just Cause games?
(dev 2) blowing sh*t up-
(dev 1) messing around with the grappling hook, that's right!
(dev 2) ...
(dev 1) so for JC4, we're gonna spend the majority of our time making the grappling hook super convoluted
(dev 2) but, shouldn't we spend more time on game play, missions, .. blowing stuff up?
(dev 1) no, see, people love to just muck around in our game, so if we give them an overly-complicated grappling hook, they'll come up with their own fun just messing around with it!
(dev 2) ... *starts fluffing up resume, and applying to jobs for some other game company, b/c Avalanche has clearly lost their GD minds*

Wish I could give it a "meh", because while it's sort of entertaining, there's too many stupid design decisions that ultimately get in the way of you having fun or accomplishing goals:

* Need to map way more buttons to do the same stuff you could do in JC3. (EG: you can't simply press "jump" to deploy parachute when free-falling. No, they make you map a separate "parachute" key now. JC has always had way too many buttons and controls, and, you know what makes it more fun.. MORE CONTROLS! *sigh*)

* Some remapped controls ignore your remap. EG: Reload defaults to "R" key. Tap to reload, hold to swap weapons. If you remap it, your remap will tap to reload, but you still have to hold "R" to swap weapons. How did this pass QA?

* Rico can only carry 2 guns. That wouldn't be so bad, but enemies are bullet sponges. So, you run out of ammo fast. Once out, Rico throws the gun away (!) This leaves you weaponless on several occasions. How do you get more weapons? You have to either air-drop them in (which is a death sentence in a fire-fight or while being pursued) or look for shimmering weapon boxes amidst the landscape.. b/c unlike JC3, the weapon locations don't show up in your HUD to make them easy to find. It makes no sense.

* You also run out of ammo easy because Heat (enemies looking for you and trying to kill you) is very hard to get rid of since ENEMIES SPAWN IN THIN AIR RIGHT BEHIND YOUR BACK. Not even joking. I was across a large river on a desolate hill side. I shot a rocket at an enemy tank across the river. Infantry enemy IMMEDIATELY SPAWNED NEAR ME. I thought I was nuts. So, I tried it again. This time, a motorcycle enemy spawned instantly on my side of the river. They don't even give the illusion of enemies chasing you; they just spawn them right on top of you behind the camera to hide it. So, it's difficult to lose heat. And, they keep ramping up the enemies as you kill them, so eventually you have TANKS, HELICOPTERS, etc spawning all over you! If you go hide in the forest, they still eagle eye you through the trees, too. So, good luck with that sh*t. It's absolutely bottom-barrel BS from the devs.

* And, speaking of BS, some moron at Avalanche seems to think everyone plays JC to muck around with the grappling hook, because they doubled-down on how convoluted it is in JC4. You can only carry TWO guns, but you get THREE load-outs for the grappling hook, where you can mix-n-match retractor, blimp and rocket booster mods.. and those mods have their own mods, like speed/strength of retraction, etc. People play JC to go blow sh*t up, so it boggles the mind that they'd spend so much time making the grappling hook even more gimicky than making the game more compelling to play. It reminds me of JC2 or JC3 where the devs had such a h***-on with doing stupid things with the grappling hook that like 1/2 the achievesments revolved around it, like "hang someone up and then shoot / kick them". Just absolutely dumb stuff you'd have to be extremely extra about. For some reason they think that's why people play JC, so that's what they focused on.. and the rest of the game is poorer for it.

* Then they decided the DLC needed more gimicky BS by throwing in a hoverboard which is annoying to use, and you're forced to use it in puzzles on ships.

* And that leads to Puzzles. So many BS puzzles. I just want to blow stuff up. But, you have 30 seconds to go here to unlock this, then you need to hoverboard over a bunch of switches in a place where it's easy to get stuck on crap within 15 seconds to unlock this, then you have 2 minutes to fly all over the place to flip several switches... I JUST WANT TO SHOOT THINGS I THE FACE AND BLOW **** UP! IT'S NOT ROCKET SCIENCE! For the love of god, why did they double-down on the puzzle BS?

* Well, at least you get something for all your hard work, right? I mean, stuff is destroyed, and... NOPE! The game auto-saves. If you quit and continue your game ALL THE STUFF YOU BLEW UP IS BACK. So, your actions have no impact on the game world in the long run.

* And, even MAIN OBJECTIVES have no impact. You not only took control of an area, but also took control of the drone production facility. Doesn't matter. TONS of enemy drones spawn around you in an AREA YOU CONTROL and absolutely wreck you. How? You took over the production facility. How is the enemy getting stronger when you're wiping out and taking over all their stuff?! It makes absolutely no sense, and underlines that YOUR HARD WORK AND ACTIONS DON'T MAKE A DIFFERENCE. Sure, a few friendlies are cruising around, and the frontline of the war has shifted. But, there's still TONS of enemies in areas YOU CONTROL. So, you can't do anything without getting swarmed. Makes no sense.

* There's the usual petty, insulting "challenges" padding the game world out, so they can brag about "hours of fun". Drive a certain car through a hoop, wing suit through some rings, etc. Bottom-barrel open world BS. Every now and then they'll have "kill this person" or "drive this person here". I wouldn't mind this if it upgraded Rico and made him better. Like, better weapons, armor, etc. NOPE! You only gain XP to unlock mods for your grappling hook to make it more convoluted. It just reminds you that some dev at Avalanche got off on how great the grappling hook was by trying to cram it down your throat.

* They do have some interesting main missions....until you realize it's a "did you enjoy that 30 min mission? Well, you get to do it 5 more times!" Again, typical Avalanche. They have a "free the hostages" mission which you get to do over and over again, b/c.. yeah, that won't get boring. Then they have a "guard the transmitter" mission where they throw tons of enemies at you that chew the transmitter apart in no time, so you fail it over and over again until you finally give up and uninstall the game. NO JOKE! You'll die a few times, then quit the game, and google to see if it's just you.. and reddits and such are FULL of folks getting demolished on this mission. It's not a fun or challenging mission. It's just an abusive "F U" from the devs who seem to not play test of QA their game, and/or think making the player fail a mission over and over again against impossible odds is some how "compelling gameplay". And, if you make it past 1 of those.. guess what.. you got more to do, because of course you do, because Avalanche loves to puppy-mill out the same stuff over and over. Good luck!

There are moments when this game shines.. like shooting out a tire and watching an enemy vehicle flip, or when everything's blowing up and you're having a blast.

But, you spend more time frustrated with stupid puzzles, unfair enemy respawns, etc than having fun, especially when (like JC 2) heat takes forever to die down (and they start rolling in tanks in like 2 minutes!) causing you to run away with your tail between your legs instead of taking everyone on like a bad-***. And then you hit a wall with some missions (like the transmitter one), and you start to think "this is not fun."

So, ultimately this is getting a down-vote from me.

115769448.review:
TL;DR: It's great but don't expect something that tops JC3 or you'll probably be disappointed.
Ok, I haven't finished the story yet but I like what I've played so far. If you've played JC2 and JC3, you may see that this is almost a mixture of the two. It has military bases similar to JC2 where you don't NEED to destroy everything but doing so rewards you with chaos. Sadly they do get rid of the city liberation mechanic, but I do enjoy the way you progress, feels more like a rebellion and not a one-man army. The open world feels more polished like from Medici in JC3, but the actual environment reminds me more of San Esperito or Panau from JC and JC2 respectively. There's TONS of side missions and objectives, some of which are kind of random encounters like the kind you'd see in JC3. I like what they've done with the characters so far, specifically the relationship with Rico and Sheldon, as they weren't on the best of terms after Medici. Now here's what I don't like, for starters, it's a nitpick I know, but it launches the game on a really low resolution to begin with, you have to raise it manually, which is fine, yeah, but first impressions y'know? I could see the pixels on the title screen for crying out loud! Next is the menus, I've never found the menus of a JC game to really be "clunky" they're usually pretty intuitive, but this is getting there, it could definitely use some polish. I REALLY, don't like the absence of a heat meter however, there's a bar at the top right that tells you if you're being watched and if they're pursuing or searching but it doesn't tell you your heat LEVEL, which there definitely are heat "levels" even if it doesn't let them be known. This causes situations where you are being pursued for a long period of time, where you do not know how hard they're going to hit you at any given point. If you saw 1 star in JC3 you knew to expect a couple jeeps and bikes, and if it was 5 stars you expected EVERYTHING, tanks, jeeps, APCs, helicopters, the whole nine yards. In JC4, when you have heat it could mean ANYTHING, you could be turning a corner and be greeted by buggies or 2 tanks and a helicopter, who knows, not you! I also did very much enjoy the little collectibles in JC3 like the Di Ravello tapes and the vehicles as a whole. It gave a nice satisfying sense of progression, and it wasn't just collectibles for the sake of collectibles, the vehicles are useful (mostly,) and the tapes fleshed out the story, if those kinda things made it into JC5 it'd be nice. Sorry for the long tangent, hope you found the review helpful!

[h1]Should have been better[/h1]
Played all the games in the series, this one is the least impressive.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]New features (Multiple pilots for drops, grappling hook addons)
[*]Huge map
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Same old formula
[*]Too few improvements
[*]Graphics same as JC3 or worse
[*]Boring story
[/list]

A bigger map on paper, but feels smaller than both JC2 and JC3 because there was no reason for me to explore the map. Different biomes are a plus.

Compared to the JC3 added features to this game are negligible, seems like it would be better to make a JC3 expansion or remaster with added features. I do like the multiple pilots for the drops.

Weather and weather weapons do nothing for me, only annoyance.

Graphics-wise, improvements are zero to none, in some places even worse, water, for instance, looks horrible.

Failed to keep my interest story-wise.

I might come back to it at some point when I have nothing else to play.

114925371.review: Just Cause 3, mejorado. Entiendo que este juego tenga unas calificaciones más bajas que el anterior, pero solo es porque no a arriesgado con ninguna innovación y en ese sentido el anterior cambió absolutamente todas las mecánicas del juego, pero eso no lo hace peor, es más, me parece mucho mejor. La historia no tiene la espectacularidad con la que cuenta el anterior, donde empiezas literalmente usando de skate un misil que va por el aire para desviarlo, pero tampoco es necesario, el sistema de conquista del mapa es mucho mejor, no te obliga a destruir cada ciudad entera para poder conquistarla, simplemente tendrás que tomar determinados puntos que dan acceso a las misiones principales de la historia y con tu nivel de caos desbloquearás tropas para ir conquistando automáticamente cada zona. Las armas son mucho mejores, el mapa está lleno de pequeños puzzles y misterios que hacen que se integren mucho mejor las mecánicas de vuelo, gancho, paracaídas, etc. Un buen juego de acción palomitero, con un punto de complejidad que hará que no lo sientas como un paseo entre balas que nunca aciertan, si no como un reto superable pero entretenido. Hasta hace unos meses no conocía esta saga y se ha convertido en una de mis favoritas dentro del género. Si como yo nunca lo habías probado, puedes jugar directamente a este o al tercero sin problema, pues son juegos totalmente independientes, y son los que yo recomendaría probar a todo el mundo. Los anteriores se quedaron demasiado anticuados, pero estos dos merecen mucho la pena, y cuando te veas planeando por sus increíbles paisajes, y gozando del diseño de niveles macro que tiene este juego, no te arrepentirás de haberles dedicado tu tiempo y dinero.

114514705.review:
So, I've now played through the entire game

It's ok. It's fun and all but it just feels uncreative.
Jc3 was my first Just cause game and it was pretty fun, by no means perfect but fun. Although it got a lot of critics that it wasn't inovative enough.
Then Jc4 is just jc3, but with some stupid features such as baloons added.
And the game runs one heck of a lot worse than just cause 3 did, forcing me to use amd fsr to get stable 60 fps at 1440P, something not needed in just cause 3, which doesn't even look that much worse.

So it's ok, you can have fun, yet i hope just cause 5 will have more inovation, maybe go even more nuts with physics, since the devs aren't bound to the old ps4 and xbox one cpus anymore which are already struggling with the game

And modding the game is more complicated, forcing you to use special executables, and such. Meanwhile jc3 just neede some folders and a launch option.

Simply said, buy it when it's on sale.

114498984.review:
It is evident just how much content is reused from JC2 and JC3 in JC4 - the vehicles are all but exactly the same as JC3, many of the visual assets used are clearly the same, character modelling is very similar - only changed slightly and the map is clearly very closely based on that of JC2, only updated and re-arranged for JC4. Even the menus and title screens are practically identical to that of JC3. All this does make for a bit of a let down in terms of overall enjoyment but the story is still pretty good and it has had a lot of new elements added to it since JC3. The map is also still rather unique and beautiful - these are probably the only reasons why I would recommend this game - story and the open-world.
It has many technical issues including glitchy physics, response times for keyboard/mouse presses are slow meaning many are either missed or delayed when you are in the action and in terms of compatibility with newer versions of Windows i.e. Windows 11... Well since this game hasn't been updated majorly in the last 2 years there are many issues especially with controller support. If you use a wired xbox controller then it is ok but forget using wireless, with constant disconnects every time you enter the map or menus, then it takes forever to reconnect.
It feels to me like JC3 was meant to be the last in the series but this opportunity of a money-grab was too tempting for the devs so here we are having something that is a re-skin of JC3! 
Look, for new players to the series or those who wont mind this sort of stuff mentioned here then it is a good game to play, but if any of these things are deal-breakers for you then maybe its worth pretending JC3 was the last of the series!

114310280.review:
I think it's a pretty good game, and I've played the story a couple times through.

Other stuff to consider:
1. There are a ton of small collection and regional missions, and I wasn't sure what many of them unlocked besides some drops. There's a bunch of mini missions where you have to go and do puzzles to discover a lost history of the island, but it does nothing and isn't central to the game's plot except for one early-game mission.
2. The DLCs aren't very good. Picking up with the comic-style cutscenes of JC3 for DLC missions was okay, but the missions themselves are either attempts to bring back the base liberation mechanic from JC3 (Danger Rising) or a ton of weird flying enemies that are hard to see and track (Los Demonios). The race DLC was okay, but many of the challenges can be beaten by dropping in late-game choppers, which seems broken.
3. The map is massive, but liberation is not player-controlled in the same way of previous games. In JC4, you complete a bunch of copy-paste missions first (hack a console, defend a radio tower, flip breakers, destroy generators, submerge car bombs in water, or liberate three prisons), and then manually unlock terrain on the map after the story missions. There are chaos objects like previous games, but they don't matter for base liberation. The repetitive missions don't do much more than eat time and unlock a single new weapon, and they get tedious quickly.
4. Removed pistols, so you can't try and solo a mission on the machine pistols or the revolvers.
5. Vehicles no longer carry infinite ammo.
6. Guns don't feel as good as they did in previous games, although some of the gimmick guns can be fun to use.
7. Story is kinda meh.
8. A lot of stuff is locked in cutscenes. You don't get to kill Espinoza (main boss) or fly down into the tornado fully. The end of the game lines up with the "hacking is everything now" gameplay, but it isn't as satisfying as when you got to take down DiRavello's chopper, execute him, and drop him in a volcano.

I would recommend it so you know whats going on for if/when JC5 comes out, but not really for the gameplay.
